A family member of the Grants of Tullochgorm, and daughter of a colonel in the Seaforth Highlanders, she was sent to London and the care of her grandfather Field Marshal Sir Patrick Grant, Goldstick-in-Waiting to Queen Victoria, and his daughter Miss Frances Gough Grant  known as 'Aunt Fan'  when her parents were posted to India. It was Aunt Fan who accompanied Elsie on early visits to museums and art galleries in London, inspiring a life-long interest in material culture and collecting. 

Later visits to folk museums in Scandinavia encouraged Elsie to dream of a museum for the Highlands and Islands that would preserve and promote a better appreciation of the rapidly disappearing material cultures and Gaelic traditions of northern and western Scotland.

Constance Eaton Hamilton (18621945) was a British-Canadian government official and activist. 

After activism supporting refugees and women in Winnipeg, she moved to Toronto and continued to support causes such as women's suffrage, becoming president of the Equal Franchise League of Toronto. 

She was elected for a one-year term on the  Toronto City Council in the 1920 elections, becoming the first female member of Toronto City Council and the first woman in Ontario to hold elected office at either the federal, provincial, or municipal level. After two terms  she resigned to continue her work campaigning for immigrant settlement and refugee issues, and for equal rights. In 1979, the Toronto city council established the Constance E. Hamilton Award on the Status of Women. 

Early life and education
She was born in Yorkshire, England in 1862 to Dr George Fowler Bodington (1829-1902) and Caroline Mary Eaton (1825-1873). Early she studied with private tutors. Fluent in German, she attended the Conservatory of Music in Leipzig, Germany and became a skilled pianist. 

She also worked as a part-time farmer for parts of her early life. Hamilton immigrated to Canada with her family in 1887 and settled in Vancouver. 

The following year she met and married Lauchlan Hamilton, an older businessman.

David William Ricketts (July 12, 1935  July 13, 2008) was an American catcher and coach in Major League Baseball who played parts of six seasons  with the St. Louis Cardinals and Pittsburgh Pirates. Ricketts was a reserve catcher on the 1967 World Series champion Cardinals and their 1968 pennant winners. 

He later served as a longtime bullpen coach of the Cardinals (19741975, 19781991), including their 1982 World Series champions and 1985 and 1987 pennant winners, after having been the bullpen coach for the Pirates from 1971 to 1973, including the 1971 World Series champions. 

Over his career, he batted .249 with 1 home run and 20 runs batted in in 130 games played. 

Ricketts was born in Pottstown, Pennsylvania; his older brother Dick was the first pick in the 1955 NBA Draft, and played three years in the National Basketball Association before pitching briefly for the  Cardinals. Dave Ricketts played basketball with his brother at Duquesne University, graduating in 1957 with a degree in education. 

He married Barbarann Boswell on August 17, 1957, and they had a daughter, Candace, and a son, David Jr., who died of spinal cancer at age 10 in 1972. He served in the military from 1958 to 1959. During his minor league career, he led Pacific Coast League catchers with 12 double plays in 1962 while with the Portland Beavers, and led International League catchers with 11 double plays the following year while with the Atlanta Crackers; he also led the IL in passed balls in both 1963 and 1964, playing for the Jacksonville Suns the latter season.

The Pre-2004 Telangana protests refers to the movements and agitations related to the Telangana movement that took place before the year 2004. Andhra state and Telangana was merged to form Andhra Pradesh state on 1 November 1956 after providing safeguards to Telangana in the form of Gentlemen's agreement. 

Soon after the formation of Andhra Pradesh, people of Telangana expressed dissatisfaction over how the agreements and guarantees were implemented. Protests initially led by students later under the leadership of newly formed political party Telangana Praja Samithi, led by M. Chenna Reddy and Konda Lakshman Bapuji, a minister who resigned from the cabinet led by then Chief Minister Kasu Brahmananda Reddy, demanding the formation of a separate state of Telangana. 

More than three hundred people died in police firing. 

Under the Mulki rules in force at the time, anyone who had lived in Hyderabad for 15 years was considered a local, and was thus eligible for certain government posts. When the Supreme Court upheld the Mulki rules at the end of 1972, the Jai Andhra movement, with the aim of re-forming a separate state of Andhra, was started in Coastal Andhra and Rayalaseema regions.

Botswana - People's Republic of China relations refers to the current and historical relationship between the Botswana and the People's Republic of China. Relations were first established on 6 January 1975. 

In 2010, upon the 35th anniversary of relations being formalized, the relationship between the two states was considered "strong" and "rapidly growing" by then Chinese ambassador to Botswana, Liu Huanxing. Botswana follows the One China Policy which means Botswana does not have relations with the Republic of China (Taiwan). 

Following the 2008 Sichuan earthquake in China, the Botswana government donated one million pula. Economic development
Beginning in the 1980s, economic and commercial relations expanded rapidly between the two countries. 

In 2008, the total trade volume between Botswana and China was nearly 360 million US dollars. 

From JanuaryOctober 2009, trade volume still totaled 193 million in 10 months despite the worldwide 2008 recession. In February 2009, Chinese officials urged Botswana to further expand economic relations, specifically in Botswana's crucial diamond industry, citing growing Chinese demand for diamonds in the face of lessening demand in the other large economies.

The China-Japan Friendship Hospital  also abbreviated as China-Japan Hospital was established through the cooperation of the Chinese and Japanese governments during the 1980s. The hospital has been directly affiliated with China's Ministry of Health since its first day of operation, October 23, 1984. 

The hospital is located on East Yinghuayuan Street, Chaoyang District, Beijing. The hospital covers , with floorspace of facilities measuring . 

Within the hospital, there are 1,500 beds, 58 departments, as well as a clinical research and education center. The hospital has intensive care and treatment of severe diseases as a primary focus and integrative eastern-western medicinal therapy as an additional area of expertise. 

The hospital often attends to the health care of senior officials from over 100 countries and regions. The hospital is the teaching hospital of Beijing University Medical School, Beijing University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, China Medical University and Tianjin Medical University, etc. 

The hospital carries out medical care, education, scientific research, preventative medicine and rehabilitation.

Count  (August 13, 1909  February 23, 1990), Riji of Hong Gakue, who was the descendant of the feudal lord of the former Takamatsu Domain, served as the International Commissioner of the Boy Scouts of Japan as well as president of the Kagawa Scout Council. 

He was one of the original founders of Japanese Scouting in 1922. Career 
Count Matsudaira, whose namesake was a daimy of the late Edo period, the ninth lord of Takamatsu, was the 13th head of the Matsudaira family. 

He established a troop in Tokyo, now Gakushin Group 1 in Toshima. 

He had an extended tour of the United States, during which he was a leader of the delegation of 22 Japanese Boy Scouts to the National Jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America, held at Irvine Ranch in southern California in July 1953 and later spent a month at the Schiff Scout Reservation in New Jersey attending the national training school for Scout executives. He also visited Arthur A. Schuck, the Chief Scout Executive at the national office of the Boy Scouts of America in New York City. In 1955, Kingsley C. Dassanaike worked to promote Scouting for the deaf and blind to Matsudaira, who would later found the Nippon Agoonoree based on their work together.

Gary Leitzell is a businessman and the former mayor of the city of Dayton, Ohio. 

He is notable for having won as an independent on a highly limited budget, as well as bringing business ideas to politics and advocating limited campaign spending. 

Biography
Leitzell was born in McKeesport, Pennsylvania in 1961. 

His father was a former member of the U.S. Air Force who worked in a steel mill; his mother was a British overseas bride. Leitzell moved as a child to Chippenham, England in 1970, where he attended a public grammar school. Leitzell graduated from the University of London with a bachelor's degree in geology in 1982 and returned to the United States to reacquaint himself with a father whom he had not seen in twelve years. Leitzell then worked in the Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania area in several sales and sales management positions until 1994. 

After two layoffs and one merger within the first ten years of his entering the corporate workforce, he made the decision to pursue a hobby-related business (miniature painting) in 1994, a decision that allowed him the opportunity to travel throughout the United States. In late 1994, he moved to Dayton, Ohio.

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a medical condition in which the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth: this allows a portion of oxygenated blood from the left heart to flow back to the lungs by flowing from the aorta, which has a higher pressure, to the pulmonary artery. Symptoms are uncommon at birth and shortly thereafter, but later in the first year of life there is often the onset of an increased work of breathing and failure to gain weight at a normal rate. With time, an uncorrected PDA usually leads to pulmonary hypertension followed by right-sided heart failure. The ductus arteriosus is a fetal blood vessel that normally closes soon after birth. 

In a PDA, the vessel does not close, but remains patent (open), resulting in an abnormal transmission of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary artery. 

PDA is common in newborns with persistent respiratory problems such as hypoxia, and has a high occurrence in premature newborns. 

Premature newborns are more likely to be hypoxic and have PDA due to underdevelopment of the heart and lungs.

"Highlights" is a song by American hip-hop artist Kanye West, from his seventh studio album, The Life of Pablo (2016). 

The song features vocals from Young Thug and The-Dream. One day before the album was released, West performed the song on Saturday Night Live with Young Thug, El DeBarge, Kelly Price and The-Dream. Within the track, West takes a shot at Ray J. 

The song was met with mixed reviews from music critics. It was revealed in July 2016 that West had a shot a music video, but it was never released. 

Background
There was an original version on Wests scrapped album So Help Me God. This album was scrapped, but it still has many songs that appear on Wests seventh studio album, such as Waves, titled Enya, and Wolves. 

The song All Day was supposed to be on The Life of Pablo as well, but it was only released as a single. The song FourFiveSeconds was supposed to be released on the album as well, but was released through Rihanna, who is featured alongside Paul McCartney as a promotional single only.

Hurricane Esther was the first large tropical cyclone to be discovered by satellite imagery. 

The fifth tropical cyclone, named storm, and hurricane of the 1961 Atlantic hurricane season, Esther developed from an area of disturbed weather hundreds of miles west-southwest of the southernmost Cape Verde Islands on September10. 

Moving northwestward, the depression strengthened into Tropical Storm Esther on September11, before reaching hurricane intensity on the following day. Early on September13, Esther curved westward and deepened into a major hurricane. The storm remained a Category3 hurricane for about four days and gradually moved in a west-northwestward direction. 

Late on September17, Esther strengthened into a Category5 hurricane with sustained winds of  on September18. The storm curved north-northeastward on September19, while offshore of North Carolina. 

Esther began to weaken while approaching New England and fell to Category3 intensity on September21. The storm turned eastward early on the following day, and rapidly weakened to a tropical storm. 

Esther then executed a large cyclonic loop, until curving northward on September25. Early on the following day, Esther struck Cape Cod, hours before emerging into the Gulf of Maine. 

Later on September26, the storm made landfall in southeastern Maine, before weakening to a tropical depression and becoming extratropical over southeastern Quebec. The remnants persisted for about 12hours, before dissipating early on September27. Between North Carolina and New Jersey, effects were primarily limited to strong winds and minor beach erosion and coastal flooding due to storm surge. In New York, strong winds led to severe crop losses and over 300,000power outages. 

High tides caused coastal flooding and damage to a number of pleasure boats. Similar impact was reported in Massachusetts. 

Additionally, some areas observed more than  of rainfall, flooding basements, low-lying roads, and underpasses. Overall, damage was minor, totaling about $6million (1961USD). 

There were also seven deaths reported when a United States Navy P5M aircraft crashed about  north of Bermuda.

Food First, also known as the Institute for Food and Development Policy, is a nonprofit organization based in Oakland, California, USA. Founded in 1975 by Frances Moore Lapp and Joseph Collins, it describes itself as a "people's think tank and education-for-action center". 

Its mission is to eliminate the injustices that cause hunger. 

According to the Food First website, its main goal is to forge food sovereignty for human rights and sustainable livelihoods, and to do so it has three programs of development: building local agri-foods systems, farmers forming food sovereignty, and democratizing development. The organization is meant to offer policy analysis on poverty, agriculture, and development, and is highly critical of the policies implemented by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. 

The organization focuses on the Green Revolution which was supported in the 1970s and which did not produce the development people hoped for. Instead it put in place a system that has high input-costs, but does not produce a yield much higher than traditional farming methods. There has been a recent resurgence of Green Revolution ideas, especially with the large-scale support of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and high-yield-variety agriculture. 

Food First claims that these policies will only further global inequalities, and has produced several policy briefs stating that the way to establish fair and effective development is through local sustainable agriculture.

Jay Walljasper (died 22 December 2020) was an American writer, editor, speaker, and community consultant. He explored how new ideas in urban planning, placemaking, tourism, community development, sustainability, politics and culture could alter urban livability for the better. 

R.T. Rybak, mayor of Minneapolis (2002-14), wrote: Ive read scores of books and articles on cities, heard by now most of the very best urban minds . . . much of what I said that mattered as mayor was deeply influenced by Jay. Career
Walljasper graduated from the University of Iowa in Iowa City, where he wrote for the Daily Iowan. At the University of Minnesota's School of Journalism and Mass Communication in 1981 he published "Age, a Minnesota perspective." 

He was urban-writer-in-residence at Augsburg University, director of strategic communications and senior fellow at Project for Public Spaces, and director of communications and collaboration for the Social Life Project. 

He worked with organizations such as the National Geographic Society, Kresge Foundation, AARP, Kaiser Permanente, Blue Zones, Minneapolis Foundation, McKnight Foundation and many others. 

According to the non-profit America Walks, he "helped walking and walkable communities gain broader appeal" through research, networking, advocacy, and journalism.

Baba Keenaram was an Aghori ascetic born in Chandauli, India. Keenaram is believed to be the originator of the Aghori sect by some sources. He was considered to be an incarnation of Lord Shiva. Early life
Aghoracharya Baba Keenaram was born on Aghor Chaturdashi (Bhadrapad) in 1601 A.D at Ramgarh village of Varanasi district (now Chandauli) of Uttar Pradesh state of India. 

The entire region became overjoyed when the childless couple Shree Akbar Singh and Mansa Devi finally got their child. After the birth, the child neither cried nor suckled at his mother's breast for three days. 

After three days when three monks (who were believed to be manifestations of Lord SadashivaBrahma, Vishnu and  Mahesh) came there, took the child in their arms and whispered something into his ears. 

Amazingly the child began to cry for the first time since birth. 

It is from that day onwards the  Lolark Shashti festival is celebrated  as Sanskar(Shashti, usually celebrated in Hindu religion after five days of birth) of Maharaj Shree Baba Kinaram. With the blessing of Hinglaj Mata (Chief Goddess of Aghora) at Lyari district of Balochistan (in present-day Pakistan), Keenaram started his spiritual journey with the message of social welfare and humanity. 

Baba Kaluram, known to be a Guru (spiritual teacher) awakened the consciousness of "Aghor" in Keenaram.

WYDO, virtual channel 14 (UHF digital channel 19), is a Fox-affiliated television station licensed to Greenville, North Carolina, United States, and serving Eastern North Carolina's Inner Banks region. 

The station is owned by Cunningham Broadcasting; the Sinclair Broadcast Group, which owns New Bern-licensed ABC affiliate WCTI-TV (channel 12), operates WYDO under a shared services agreement (SSA). However, Sinclair effectively owns WYDO as the majority of Cunningham's stock is owned by the family of deceased group founder Julian Smith. 

The two stations share studios on Glenburnie Drive in New Bern and transmitter facilities north of Trenton along NC 41. There is no separate website for WYDO; instead, it is integrated with that of sister station WCTI-TV. 

The station's main signal was originally WFXI (virtual and VHF digital channel 8), licensed to Morehead City. WFXI's signal covered the eastern portion of the market, while WYDO served as a full satellite for the western portion. 

On September 6, 2017, WFXI was shut down as a result of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC)'s spectrum auction, leaving WYDO as the sole Fox affiliate for the region. At the same time, the station was sold by Esteem Broadcastingan affiliate of WCTI owner Bonten Media Groupto Cunningham Broadcasting, a partner company of Sinclair (which had acquired Bonten).

Shellshock: Nam '67 is a 2004 third-person shooter video game developed by Guerrilla Games and published by Eidos Interactive for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 2, and Xbox. 

Plot
The game starts in January 1967 in Saigon, South Vietnam. 

A CH-47 Chinook containing Caleb "Cal" Walker, the game's protagonist, and other G.I.s, lands at Tan Son Nhut Air Base in southern Saigon. Walker, along with his squad mate, Private "Psycho" Kowalski, are chosen by Colonel Salter, the CO, to participate in an air assault on a Viet Cong encampment within Kon Tum province. Walker and Kowalski are put under the command of Lieutenant O'Brien along with another G.I. nicknamed "Short Timer". As Caleb and his squad proceed through the area, a friendly fire incident, involving flawed mortar coordinates, forces another G.I. named Tompkins, to join the squad. 

Along with the help of a special operations squad made up of Sergeant Ramirez, "Tick Tock" and "Eyeball", they help Walker and the others clear out the VC encampment. 

The encampment is soon after converted to a fire base, which serves as a headquarters for Walker and his unit.

Karl Wilhelm (Vasily Georgievich) Brandt (Willi Brandt) (18691923) was a German-Russian trumpeter, pedagogue, and composer. 

He was born and educated in Coburg, and after a period of working alternatively in the spa orchestra in Bad Oeynhausen and in Helsinki, he moved to Russia. He became principal trumpet of the Bolshoi Theater in 1890 and became first cornet in 1903. He succeeded Theodor Richter (18261901) as the trumpet professor of the Moscow Conservatory in 1900, and also taught band orchestration there. He is considered the founder of the Russian trumpet school. 

His 34 Orchestral Etudes, is an important study material for modern trumpet players. His two Concert Pieces for trumpet and piano are also widely performed today. 

Brandt joined the faculty of the Saratov Conservatory in 1912. 

Among his students are Pyotr Lyamin (18841968) who succeeded Brandt as a professor at the Saratov Conservatory; Pavel Klochkov (18841966) who was an early Russian recording artist; Vladimir Drucker (18981974) who was a principal trumpet with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; and Mikhail Tabakov (18771956) who became professor at the Moscow Conservatory. Several of his compositions and etude books are published by International Music Company.

The Campeonato Nacional de Liga de Primera Divisin, commonly known simply as Primera Divisin in Spain, and as La Liga in English-speaking countries and officially as LaLiga Santander for sponsorship reasons, stylized as LaLiga, is the men's top professional football division of the Spanish football league system. Administered by the Liga Nacional de Ftbol Profesional, it is contested by 20 teams, with the three lowest-placed teams at the end of each season being relegated to the Segunda Divisin and replaced by the top two teams and a play-off winner in that division. 

Since its inception, a total of 62 teams have competed in La Liga. Nine teams have been crowned champions, with Real Madrid winning the title a record 34 times. 

During the 1940s Valencia, Atltico Madrid and Barcelona emerged as the strongest clubs, winning several titles. 

Real Madrid and Barcelona dominated the championship in the 1950s, each winning four La Liga titles during the decade. 

During the 1960s and 1970s, Real Madrid dominated La Liga, winning 14 titles, with Atltico Madrid winning four. During the 1980s and 1990s Real Madrid were prominent in La Liga, but the Basque clubs of Athletic Club and Real Sociedad had their share of success, each winning two Liga titles. From the 1990s onward, Barcelona have dominated La Liga, winning 16 titles to date. Although Real Madrid has been prominent, winning nine titles, La Liga has also seen other champions, including Atltico Madrid, Valencia, and Deportivo La Corua.

Albrecht Drer (; ; ; 21 May 1471  6 April 1528), sometimes spelled in English as Durer (without an umlaut) or Duerer, was a German painter, printmaker, and theorist of the German Renaissance. Born in Nuremberg, Drer established his reputation and influence across Europe in his twenties due to his high-quality woodcut prints. 

He was in contact with the major Italian artists of his time, including Raphael, Giovanni Bellini, and Leonardo da Vinci, and from 1512 was patronized by Emperor Maximilian I. Drer's vast body of work includes engravings, his preferred technique in his later prints, altarpieces, portraits and self-portraits, watercolours and books. The woodcuts series are more Gothic than the rest of his work. 

His well-known engravings include the three Meisterstiche (master prints) Knight, Death and the Devil (1513), Saint Jerome in his Study (1514), and Melencolia I (1514). His watercolours mark him as one of the first European landscape artists, while his woodcuts revolutionised the potential of that medium.

Lissy Jarvik (ne Feingold; March 17, 1924  October 1, 2021) was a Dutch-born American geriatric psychiatrist. The National Library of Medicine featured her in their interactive "Changing the Face of Medicine" exhibit, describing her as "a pioneer in the field of neuropsychogeriatrics." 

Early life and education
Jarvik was born Lissy Feingold in the Hague, Netherlands on March 17, 1924. Her family was Jewish. In 1940, she and her family received a travel visa from Aristides de Sousa Mendes, which they used to flee the Netherlands for the United States. In 1946, she graduated cum laude from Hunter College. She went on to earn her master's degree and Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1947 and 1950, respectively. 

While studying for her doctorate at Columbia, she began working on a twin study with her mentor, Franz Josef Kallmann, with whom she traveled around New York to catalog medical and psychological data on twins. 

In 1954, she received her M.D. 

from Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine in 1954.

Kisses is the fourth studio album by Brazilian singer Anitta, released on April 5, 2019, through Warner Music Brasil. It is a trilingual visual album, with songs in Portuguese, Spanish and English, and music videos for each track. It received a Latin Grammy nomination for Best Urban Music Album. 

Background
In 2016, after completing promotion for her third studio album Bang, Anitta began planning an international career and started releasing a series of collaborations including singles with artists such as Maluma, Iggy Azalea and Major Lazer during 2016 and 2017 in order to start the process of establishing her career outside of Brazil. 

The collaboration with Iggy Azalea, "Switch", marked the first time Anitta released a song in which she sings in English. 

A single named "Paradinha", which is sung in Spanish, followed in 2017 and became one of Anitta's biggest hits in Brazil whilst also charting in other countries such as Mexico and Portugal. In July, 2017, Billboard announced Anitta signed with Shots Studios for management outside of Brazil and that she was working on an English-language album which would feature Marshmello, Alesso and Poo Bear.

Farshid Jamshidian is a finance researcher, academic and practitioner. His experience covers both fixed-income and equity research and trading. 

Dr. Jamshidian has made important contributions to the theory of derivatives pricing, and has published extensively, especially on interest rate modelling, amongst other contributions, developing the use of the forward measure, and "Jamshidian's trick", widely applied in the pricing of bond options. He is professor of Applied Mathematics at the University of Twente, and is at NIBC Bank. 

He is a member of the Editorial Board  of The Journal of Fixed Income. 

Previously he was managing director of NetAnalytic, a risk management products and services company he founded in 1999; Managing Director of New Products and Equity Derivatives at Sakura Global Capital; Executive Director of Technical Trading at Fuji International Finance; and head of quantitative fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch. As an academic, he was an associate editor of Finance and Stochastics and The Journal of Computational Finance and served as a faculty member in the mathematics departments at the University of Chicago and the University of California, Berkeley.

Howard Earl Bailey Jr. (born March 9, 1980), known professionally as Chingy, is an American rapper, record producer and actor. Chingy grew up in St. Louis, Missouri and began rapping in his late teens. 

He toured as an opening act with Nelly in the summer of 2002 and then became a protg of Ludacris, who signed him to his newly formed Disturbing Tha Peace (DTP) record label. 

The rapper's 2003 summer debut single, "Right Thurr", put him on the musical map as a good-time rapper who specialized in catchy, club-friendly beats and simplistic lyrics delivered in a sing-song, nursery rhyme style. 

Chingy's 2003 debut album, Jackpot, sold two million copies, thanks to the boost from "Right Thurr". A second album, Powerballin', was released in 2004 to mixed reviews, and his 2006 release Hoodstar spawned the hit singles "Pullin' Me Back" (featuring Tyrese Gibson) and "Dem Jeans" (featuring Jermaine Dupri). 

In 2007, his fourth album, Hate It or Love It was released under Disturbing tha Peace, preceded by lead single "Fly Like Me" (featuring Amerie). A studio album, Success & Failure, was released in 2010. In 2018, he made his official debut as a record producer with his single Sparks Fly which debuted on July 4, 2018.

Delhi Public School Barra is a private school running under the aegis of the Delhi Public School Society, New Delhi in Kanpur in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. 

This school is affiliated to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), New Delhi. 

DPS Barra is located in Barra at Meharban Singh ka Purwa, besides River Pandu (a tributary of River Ganga). Overview
Established in 2010, DPS Barra functions under the leadership and supervision of its founder Principal, Mrs. Shilpa Manish. 

Moreover, DPS Kidwai Nagar was established at K-Block, Kidwai Nagar in 2011 as a feeder school for DPS Barra. 

DPS Barra, located in a 14-acre campus is a co-educational school. The School has of an Administrative Block and an Academic Block. The Academic Block has a Primary section for classes Play Group - Class V while the Middle Section resides classes VI - VIII. The Senior Section consists of classes IX  X. 

The School has an amphitheater, a multipurpose hall, playground, academic Labs and  a library. The school also conducts classes for extracurricular activities such as Music, Dance, Theater, and Fine Arts.

Chteau Vaudreuil was a stately residence and college in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. 

It was constructed between 1723 and 1726 for Philippe de Rigaud, Marquis de Vaudreuil, as his private residence by Gaspard-Joseph Chaussegros de Lry. Though the Chteau Saint-Louis in Quebec City remained the official residence of the Governors General of New France, the Chteau Vaudreuil was to remain as their official home in Montreal up until the British Conquest in 1763. 

In 1767, it was purchased by the Marquis de Lotbinire. 

He sold it in 1773, when it became the Collge Saint-Raphal. It was destroyed by a fire in 1803. 

Completed in 1726, it was built in the classical style of the French Htel Particulier by King Louis XV's chief engineer in New France, Gaspard-Joseph Chaussegros de Lry. The central building was flanked by two wings with two sets of semi-circular stairs leading up to a terrace and the main entrance. It stood beyond the end of Rue Saint-Paul, which was kept clear of buildings on that side to afford it a clear view, while formal gardens led up to Notre-Dame Street.

Marat Mubinovich Safin  (born 27 January 1980) is a Russian retired world No. 1 tennis player and former politician. He achieved the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) world No. 

1 singles ranking on 20 November 2000. 

Safin is also the older brother of former WTA world No. 

1 player Dinara Safina. They are the only brother-sister tandem in tennis history who have both achieved No. 1 rankings. 

Safin began his professional tennis career in 1997, and held the No. 1 ranking for a total of 9 weeks between November 2000 and April 2001. 

He won his first Grand Slam title at the 2000 US Open, defeating Pete Sampras in the final, and won the 2005 Australian Open, defeating Lleyton Hewitt in the final. Safin helped lead Russia to Davis Cup victories in 2002 and 2006. 

Despite his dislike of grass courts, he became the first Russian man to reach the semifinals of Wimbledon at the 2008 Wimbledon Championships, where he lost to Roger Federer. At the time of his retirement in November 2009, he was ranked world No. 

61. 

In 2011, he became a member of the State Duma representing the United Russia party. In 2016, he became the first Russian tennis player inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

Cosimo de Torres also Cosmo de Torres and Cosma de Torres (15841642) was a Roman Catholic cardinal who served as Cardinal-Priest of Santa Maria in Trastevere (16411642), Cardinal-Priest of San Pancrazio (16231641), Archbishop of Monreale (16341642), Bishop of Perugia (16241634), Apostolic Nuncio to Poland (16211622), and Titular Archbishop of Hadrianopolis in Haemimonto (16211622). 

Biography
Cosimo de Torres was born to a noble family in Rome, Italy in 1584, the son of Marchis Giovanni de Torres and Giulia Mattei, princess of Papareschi. 

His family was of Spanish descent having moved from Mlaga, Spain in the early 16th century. His uncles Girolamo Mattei (named cardinal in 1586) and Ludovico de Torres, iuniore (named cardinal in 1606) were also cardinals. 

Torres obtained a doctorate in utroque iure in canon and civil law from the University of Perugia. After school, he was assigned to the college of protonotaries apostolic under the guidance of his uncle, Cardinal Mattei. In 1608, he served on the Referendary of the Tribunals of the Apostolic Signature of Justice and of Grace.

Mark Gregor Strang Donaldson,  (born 2 April 1979) is an Australian soldier and a recipient of the Victoria Cross for Australia, the highest award in the Australian honours system. Then Trooper Donaldson was a member of the Special Air Service Regiment (SASR) when he exposed himself to enemy fire to protect injured troops and then rescued an interpreter under heavy enemy fire in the Battle of Khaz Oruzgan during Operation Slipper, the Australian contribution to the War in Afghanistan. 

He was presented with the decoration by the Governor-General of Australia, Quentin Bryce, in a ceremony in Canberra on 16 January 2009. On 25 January 2010, Donaldson was named the 2010 Young Australian of the Year. He was promoted to corporal in June 2010. 

Early life
Donaldson was born on 2 April 1979 in Waratah, New South Wales, the younger son of Greg, a Vietnam War veteran, and Bernadette Donaldson. He grew up in the small northern New South Wales township of Dorrigo, attending Dorrigo High School, a small state public school, until 1996. 

In 1995 his father died suddenly of a heart attack and Mark and his brother became wards of Legacy, one of their legatees being a former member of the same Army unit their father had served in.

Dharmapala was a pioneering broadcaster and Outside Broadcast Engineer of Radio Ceylon, the oldest radio station in South Asia, for 42 years (1922-1964). 

With the help of the engineers from Radio Ceylon, he was able to convert the radio equipment from a German submarine, captured during World War I, into a 0.5 kw radio transmitter. Using this, the first experimental broadcasts, playing gramophone music, were conducted in 1923 from the Central Telegraph Department. On December 16, 1925, barely three years after the BBC was inaugurated in England, Ceylon became the first British colony in Southeast Asia to begin regular, official radio broadcasts. In 1929 Dharmapala's was the first Sinhala voice heard over the airwaves of Radio Ceylon, broadcasting the words Colombin katha karami (This is Colombo calling). In 1954, he was appointed as assistant engineer for Radio Ceylon. 

Dharmapala pioneered the way with outside broadcasts and was fully involved in the Buddha Jayanti activities all over the island. 

Dharmapala's technical expertise was invaluable to Radio Ceylon.

Robert Kyjuan Cleveland, (born April 1976) (pronounced 'Kee-Wahn'), is an American rapper. 

He hails from St. Louis, Missouri, and is also a founding member of the Platinum-selling rap group the St. Lunatics. 

Kyjuan brought younger brother Murphy Lee to become a "Lunatic". Kyjuan has not released a solo album yet, but has released two albums with the St. Lunatics. Kyjuan can also be seen from videos from Nelly to Chicago's own Shawnna.

Thalamus segmentation plays a critical role in studying various brain disorders and understanding functional connectivity. This paper presents a novel multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for thalamus segmentation. 

Our method utilizes multiple MRI contrasts, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted images, to leverage the complementary information they provide. We propose a deep learning framework that combines convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks to achieve accurate and robust thalamus segmentation. 

Experimental results on a large dataset demonstrate the superiority of our approach compared to state-of-the-art methods and highlight the potential of multi-contrast MRI for improved thalamus segmentation. Overall, this paper contributes to advancing the field of neuroimaging by presenting a promising technique for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast MRI.

Power-Law Graph Cuts is an academic paper that introduces a novel algorithm for graph cuts based on power-law distributions. The paper presents a new approach to graph partitioning that leverages the inherent power-law structure of real-world networks. 

The algorithm is designed to efficiently handle large-scale graphs and is shown to outperform existing methods in terms of both runtime and solution quality. The paper also provides theoretical analysis and experimental results to support the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. 

Overall, Power-Law Graph Cuts offers a valuable contribution to the field of graph partitioning and provides a promising solution for various applications in network analysis and optimization.

This paper presents a novel approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images using a shape-refined multi-task deep learning method. The proposed method combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a shape refinement module to accurately segment the left and right ventricles in cardiac images. 

The CNN is trained on a large dataset of annotated cardiac images to learn the spatial and contextual information necessary for accurate segmentation. 

The shape refinement module then refines the initial segmentation results by incorporating shape priors and enforcing smoothness constraints. Experimental results on a publicly available dataset demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy and robustness. The proposed method has the potential to improve the diagnosis and treatment planning of cardiac diseases by providing accurate and reliable segmentation of the ventricles in cardiac images.

This paper investigates the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. 

The authors provide a comprehensive analysis of the various types of curvature tensors that can be defined on such manifolds, including the Ricci curvature tensor, the scalar curvature tensor, and the Weyl curvature tensor. The paper also explores the relationships between these curvature tensors and their properties. 

The authors present several examples and applications of these curvature tensors in the context of Hermitian manifolds. Overall, this paper contributes to the understanding of the geometric properties of Hermitian manifolds and provides a foundation for further research in this area.

This academic paper presents a novel method for joint segmentation and localization in videos and images by introducing the concept of foreground clustering. The proposed method first generates a set of candidate segment proposals using a pre-trained convolutional neural network. 

Then, a foreground clustering algorithm is applied to group these proposals into coherent foreground objects. This clustering algorithm utilizes both appearance and motion cues to capture the spatio-temporal coherence of the foreground objects. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed method in accurately segmenting and localizing foreground objects in videos and images. 

This method has potential applications in computer vision tasks such as video object segmentation, object tracking, and scene understanding.

In this paper, we present a multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for segmenting the thalamus. The approach is based on the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted MRI scans. The fusion is performed using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (CNN). 

The CNN is trained on a large dataset of thalamus segments from different MRI contrasts. 

The resulting model is evaluated on a separate test dataset, and results show that the approach is able to accurately segment the thalamus. The segmented thalamus can then be used for further analysis, such as brain connectivity analysis. 

This paper makes a contribution to the field of MRI-based brain segmentation by introducing a multi-contrast approach that leverages the complementary information from different MRI contrasts. The approach is evaluated on a large dataset and shows promise for accurate thalamus segmentation. The segmented thalamus can be used for various brain studies, including brain connectivity analysis. Keywords: Brain segmentation, Thalamus, Magnetic resonance imaging, Convolutional neural network


Abstract:

Thalamus is a vital brain structure that connects the brain to various other parts of the body. Magnetic 
resonance imaging (MRI) is a useful tool for studying the thalamus and other brain structures. 

In this paper, we present a multi-contrast MRI approach for segmenting the thalamus. 

The approach is based on the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted MRI scans, performed using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (CNN). The CNN is trained on a large dataset of thalamus segments from different MRI

We introduce power-law graph cuts, a new algorithmic framework for electromagnetic tomography (EMT). EMT reconstructs a conductivity distribution inside a uniformly-conductive, opaque, and periodic sample from boundary measurements of electric fields. The classical approach to EMT reconstruction is based on the Kirchhoff approximation (KA), in which the conductivity is parameterized by a finite number of parameters, and the inverse problem is solved as a nonlinear optimization problem. 

The KA performs poorly when the parameterized conductivity distorts significantly the internal electric fields. 

We show that power-law graph cuts, a novel convex optimization approach, are capable of recovering the true conductivity distribution accurately even in the presence of significant distortion.

Recent works have shown that Deep Learning (DL) methods can be used for myocardial segmentation, however, most of these methods focus on the left ventricle (LV) only. 

In this work, we present a fully automatic bi-ventricular segmentation approach based on a Shape-Refined Multi-Task Deep Learning (SRMTDL) framework. Our approach incorporates prior knowledge of the global shape of the left ventricle and the right ventricle, and models the complex ventricle-atrium relationship in the cardiac structure. 

Specifically, we propagate the mesh-based shape prior in the volumetric space using a Shape Refinement Network (SRN), and combine it with a Multi-Task Deep Learning (MTDL) framework to simultaneously segment the left and right ventricles and the left and right atria. We evaluated our approach on 320 cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) datasets from the 2017 Cardiac bundling challenge (CBC), and achieved a mean Inter-User Agreement (IUA) of 0.829 and a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.837 on the LV, and a mean IUA of 0.842 and DSC of 0.839 on the RV.

In this short note we calculate the curvature tensors of a Hermitian manifold whose first Chern class is a positive integer multiple of the canonical class. This generalizes a result of Sato on the curvature of compact Hermitian manifolds.

We present a novel approach for joint segmentation and localization of objects in videos and images. Our method exploits the spatial coherence of objects in image and video frames for jointly optimizing object segments and their respective bounding boxes. Towards this end, we introduce an energy function that tightly integrates a segmentation term, based on a variation of the popular GrabCut algorithm, and a localization term, based on a new objectness measure that we introduce for this purpose. 

To efficiently optimize the energy function, we propose a novel foreground clustering technique, allowing us to deal with sparse, irregular object pixel assignments, while providing for simultaneous estimation of object segments and bounding boxes. 

In order to assess our method's performance, we introduce a new fully-automatic evaluation metric that gauges localization accuracy, as compared to ground truth object bounding boxes. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on the VOC 2012 segmentation benchmark, considerably improving over the previous best method on this dataset, while running at nearly real-time speed. 

Furthermore, we show that our foreground clustering technique, when applied to other recent joint segmentation and localization methods, improves their performance as well, thus making our method a strong baseline for future research.

In this paper, we present "UNet++," an improved version of the popular U-Net architecture for medical image segmentation. U-Net is a convolutional neural network (CNN) that has shown promising results in various medical image segmentation tasks. However, it can be challenging to train U-Net on certain datasets due to its fully connected structure, which can lead to overfitting and poor generalization performance. 

To address these issues, we propose a nested U-Net architecture that incorporates a series of dilated convolutions and residual connections to improve the model's performance. Our proposed architecture is easy to train and generalize, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on three different medical image segmentation datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in two of them. 

We believe that our proposed architecture will serve as a strong foundation for future research in medical image segmentation.

Graph cuts are an effective and efficient algorithmic technique used to partition graphs into two subgraphs while minimizing the cut size. In this paper, we explore the use of power laws to optimize the graph cut process. 

We propose a new algorithm that utilizes power laws to determine the optimal cut size, resulting in improved performance over traditional graph cuts. 

Our experimental results demonstrate that our proposed algorithm achieves significant speedup and improved cut quality compared to existing techniques. This work has implications for various applications such as image segmentation, mesh segmentation, and social network analysis.

Here is an abstract for the academic paper "A Statistical Mechanical Approach to Protein Aggregation":

Protein aggregation is a complex process that involves the formation of larger protein assemblies from smaller, individual proteins. 

It is a common feature of many diseases, including neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. 

In this paper, we develop a statistical mechanical approach to protein aggregation, based on the idea that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically favorable process. We use a simple model system to study the aggregation of a small protein, and we find that our approach is able to accurately predict the aggregation behavior of the protein. Our results suggest that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically driven process, and that our approach can be used to study the aggregation of proteins in a variety of diseases.

This paper shows that the category of determinantal varieties admits a morphism to the category of singular varieties that preserves limits and is an isomorphism on the level of sets. This extends a result of M. Pun and T. Peternell for rational singularities to an arbitrary characteristic.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "RA-UNet: A hybrid deep attention-aware network to extract liver and tumor in CT scans" could be:

This paper proposes a hybrid deep attention-aware network (RA-UNet) for the extraction of liver and tumor in CT scans. The network combines the strengths of a UNet-based architecture and a attention-based mechanism to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the extraction process. 

The RA-UNet utilizes a series of convolutional layers and attention mechanisms to capture the spatial and contextual information in the CT scans. The proposed network was evaluated on a public dataset and achieved state-of-the-art performance in terms of accuracy and efficiency. 

The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in extracting liver and tumor in CT scans.

Liquid samples are an important part of medical tests. Recently, it has been shown that large-scale deep convolutional neural networks can significantly improve the performance in predicting the shape and contour of microfluid. 

The goal of this paper is to apply these techniques to image segmentation and prediction of liquid samples. 

Our approach has two main components: image segmentation and prediction of relations between features. In addition, we study the performance of two machine learning techniques, the nearest neighbor metric and the MLE algorithm. The methods presented in the paper are also part of a research project by the Medical School at the University. The paper will be presented at ICML 2015 in Tokyo. A new study shows that B-COSFIRE filters, which map noise levels on an object's surface to its depth in two dimensions, represent in a similar fashion lines on a surface. For example, when the spatial resolution of the image is large, a B-COSFIRE filter can be used to distinguish between two surfaces, such as the image on the right (from an article by Zoltn Istvn, published in the journal Scientific Reports). 

Credit: Zoltn Istvn/Shutterstock.com. A new study shows that B-COSFIRE (B-COSFIRE-enhanced spectral imaging by line-source Faint extinction + High noise index), which can map noise levels on an object's surface to its depth in two dimensions, represents in a similar fashion lines on a surface. 

This new technique, which we demonstrate on a range of images, represents not only in a comparable manner lines on an object's surface, but also any object that is detected to be a particular size. 

These methods will lead to improved applications in mapping the physical and geological structures in image data at sub-exposure levels. This is the second article in the series "Delineation of line patterns in images using B-COSFIRE filters" where we have analyzed the accuracy of B-COSFIRE (see our previous article about this). More specifically, we show that not merely does B-COSFIRE-enhanced spectral imaging by line source Faint extinction + High noise index provide good color discrimination when the spatial resolution is very large (which includes digital cameras), but we can also discriminate between two objects that are detected to be the same size, such as those shown in the image on the right.

A simple method based on partial derivatives with respect to the parameters , t and d for variational Bayes estimation is evaluated in this work. 

In this approach a video is represented as an object sequence, where i j refers to position or rotation of one image element j at time t, along line ij (vertical) of frames corresponding to frames with coordinates specified by i i = jj + [t/2] and  i denotes the prior expectation parameter for image element j in the current frame. By integrating such differential equations over both horizontal and vertical planes with respect to the interval [3, 6],  j (t) can be used to compute the gradient vector, which can then be used in variational bayesian inference for image segmenting. Hereby, we refer to two features : (i) a continuous property called distance between objects relative to the video itself; and (ii) a discrete property known as feature vectors and used as weights in the regression algorithm. 

Finally, to determine the number of steps required to obtain reliable results, several empirical tests are carried out in conjunction with numerical examples.

The purpose of this study was to investigate brain segmentation potentials during CUSUM scanning using high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and contrast MRI in a patient cohort with hippocampal damage induced by stroke, with T1 weighted imaging data. 

Three groups, diagnosed as having early or late anterior temporal lobe (ATL) lesions at baseline were exposed to two scan sessions separated 50 days apart: One session without a scan, one with an echo-planar imaging (EPI) cusum tube, one consisting of a full head CT scan only with the help of an artificial brain. During both scans sessions T1 weighted images could be acquired in order to determine regions potentially contributing to normal tissue preservation after traumatic insult and the number and location of those regions were compared between the groups that could have different injury locations on examination. 

This methodology should pave the path toward the development of high dynamic range nonlinear cusums such as SPM2/3s with low signal attenuation, low background noise and small spatial volume (SV). We suggest that brain segments produced by SPM2/3 may aid cognitive neuroscience investigation such as determining whether or not certain regions are associated prior to any pathological insult such as stroke in patients suffering from hippocampal loss induced by cortical lesion.

In this paper we present a method for automated thalamus segmentation in MRI using a multi-contrast approach. We combine T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and T2 FLAIR images in a single registration and segmentation framework using a combination of atlas-based and model-based methods. We evaluate our method on a dataset of 30 subjects, and compare our results to those of a state-of-the-art thalamus segmentation method. 

Our results show that our method outperforms the state-of-the-art in terms of accuracy, while being significantly faster.

We propose a new method for finding graph cuts which is based on the power-law degree distribution of the graph. Our method is able to find graph cuts which are significantly better than those found by other methods, while being much faster.

In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images. 

Our approach is based on a shape-refined multi-task deep learning framework, which consists of two sub-networks: a shape network and a segmentation network. 

The shape network is used to generate a shape prior for the segmentation network. The segmentation network is then trained to segment the left ventricle (LV) and right ventricle (RV) simultaneously, using the shape prior from the shape network. We evaluated our approach on the ACDC challenge dataset, and the results showed that our approach outperformed the state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

In this paper, we study the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. We prove that the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds satisfy certain identities which are generalizations of the well-known identities satisfied by the curvature tensors of Riemannian manifolds. 

As a consequence, we obtain a characterization of the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds in terms of the Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature.

With the advent of powerful Deep Neural Networks (DNNs), semantic segmentation of images and videos has seen significant improvement in recent years. However, most existing methods are limited to segmenting a single object category in an image or video. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to joint segmentation and localization of multiple object categories in images and videos. Our method is based on a new method for foreground clustering, which we call foregroundness-aware clustering. 

This method is able to cluster foreground objects in an image or video, while also accounting for their spatial layout. 

We then use the clustered foreground objects to train a DNN for joint segmentation and localization. 

We evaluate our method on the challenging Youtube-Objects dataset, and show that it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods for joint segmentation and localization.

This paper presents a novel approach for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). 

The focus of the study is to enhance the accuracy, efficiency, and effectiveness of thalamus identification and volumetric analysis in the human brain via MRI. The method utilized a combination of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted contrasts to differentiate between thalamus and non-thalamus structures. Experimental results indicate that our multi-contrast MRI approach significantly improves thalamus segmentation compared to traditional single-contrast methods, promising potential applications in studying various neurological conditions that impact the thalamus.

This paper presents an in-depth study on Power-Law Graph Cuts, a novel approach to partitioning large-scale graphs. 

The study explores the theoretical underpinnings of the power-law distribution in graph cuts and its implications for network analysis. The paper also introduces an efficient algorithm for computing power-law graph cuts, demonstrating its effectiveness through extensive experiments on various real-world datasets. The results show that power-law graph cuts can provide more accurate and meaningful partitions than traditional methods, especially for graphs with skewed degree distributions. 

This research opens up new possibilities for analyzing and understanding complex networks in various fields, including social networks, web graphs, and biological networks.

This paper presents an innovative deep learning approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images. The proposed method leverages a multi-task learning framework that simultaneously performs segmentation and shape regression tasks, thereby improving the accuracy and robustness of the segmentation results. 

The model is trained on a large dataset of cardiac images, and its performance is evaluated against manual segmentations by expert radiologists. 

The results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms existing methods in terms of both segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. This research has significant implications for the development of automated tools for cardiac image analysis, potentially improving the diagnosis and treatment of heart diseases.

This paper delves into the intricate study of curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. It provides a comprehensive analysis of the properties and characteristics of these tensors, focusing on their role in the geometry and topology of Hermitian manifolds. The paper also explores the relationship between curvature tensors and other geometric entities, such as the Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature. 

The results obtained contribute to the understanding of the geometric structure of Hermitian manifolds and have potential applications in differential geometry, theoretical physics, and other related fields. 

The paper concludes with a discussion on the implications of the findings and suggestions for future research.

This paper addresses the task of joint segmentation and localization in both videos and images by introducing a novel method, 'Foreground Clustering'. The method oversees identifying and clustering foreground pixels that share similar object-level properties while discerning them from the background. 

The authors articulate a new algorithm that assimilates both spatial and temporal cues, simultaneously localizing and segmenting foreground objects efficiently. 

It surpasses traditional methods, which perform these tasks separately, improving both accuracy and speed. The presented experimental results show that this Foreground Clustering method outperforms existing state-of-the-art techniques on several benchmark datasets, leading to more precise and efficient segmentation and localization in videos and images.

Abstract:

Left atrial segmentation from 3D gadolinium enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a crucial step in diagnosing and managing cardiac arrhythmias. However, manual segmentation of the left atrium can be time-consuming and observer-dependent, leading to variability in clinical decision-making. 

In this study, we propose a deep learning approach using dilated convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) for automated left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI. Our proposed method utilizes a combination of spatial pyramid pooling and multi-scale features fusion to improve feature extraction and enhance performance. We evaluated our method on a dataset of 100 patients and compared it with traditional CNNs and U-Net architectures. 

The results show that DCNNs outperformed both traditional CNNs and U-Nets in terms of segmentation accuracy, achieving an average Dice similarity coefficient of 86.5%. Additionally, we observed that DCNNs were more robust to variations in heart rate and image quality compared to other methods. 

These findings suggest that DCNNs are a promising tool for accurate and efficient left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI, which could potentially improve the consistency and efficiency of clinical decision-making in cardiology.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to improve the performance of fully convolutional networks (FCNs) by learning what to attend to in images. 

Our approach, called AttentionBoost, leverages the strengths of recent attention mechanisms to boost the performance of FCNs in various computer vision tasks. 

Existing attention mechanisms have shown promising results in natural language processing and image captioning, but they have limitations when applied to image classification and object detection tasks. 

Specifically, these mechanisms are designed to focus on specific parts of an image, but they often struggle to identify the most relevant regions when dealing with complex images or multiple objects. AttentionBoost addresses this issue by introducing a novel attention module that learns to attend to the most discriminative regions of an image. 

Our module is designed to be lightweight and can be easily integrated into existing FCN architectures. We evaluate AttentionBoost on several benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and PASCAL VOC. 

The key contribution of this paper is the introduction of a novel attention mechanism that learns to attend to the most discriminative regions of an image, leading to improved performance in image classification and object detection tasks. 

Our approach outperforms existing attention mechanisms and achieves state-of-the-art results on several benchmarks. The paper is organized as follows: In section 2, we review related work on attention mechanisms and their applications in computer vision. In section 3, we introduce the AttentionBoost module and its architecture. In section 4, we describe the experimental setup and the datasets used for evaluation. In section 5, we present the results of our experiments and compare AttentionBoost with existing attention mechanisms. 

Finally, in section 6, we conclude the paper and discuss future directions for improving AttentionBoost. Overall, AttentionBoost offers a promising approach to improving the performance of FCNs in various computer vision tasks, and we believe it has the potential to be widely adopted in the field.

This paper proposes a new approach to modeling spatial data using dynamic spatial autoregressive (SAR) models that account for both autoregressive and heteroskedastic disturbances. The proposed model, called the dynamic SAR(p,d,q) model, extends the traditional SAR model by incorporating time-varying parameters and heteroskedastic disturbances, which allows for a more flexible and realistic representation of spatial data. 

The model is estimated using a Bayesian approach, which allows for the incorporation of prior information and provides a natural way to handle model uncertainty. The paper also discusses the use of informative prior distributions and provides guidance on how to choose appropriate priors. 

The model is applied to a real-world dataset and the results show that it outperforms traditional SAR models in terms of forecast accuracy and ability to capture spatial patterns. The paper concludes by discussing the contributions and limitations of the proposed model and suggesting directions for future research. 

Keywords: spatial data, dynamic spatial autoregressive models, heteroskedastic disturbances, Bayesian estimation, informative priors.

In this paper, we investigate homotopy invariants of combings of 3-manifolds. 

A combing of a 3-manifold is a way of decomposing it into smaller pieces, called teeth, that are glued together along their boundaries in a specific way. We focus on homotopy invariants of combings, which are properties that remain unchanged under continuous deformations of the combing. 

We first establish a framework for studying homotopy invariants of combings by defining a notion of homotopy between combings and introducing a category whose objects are combings and whose morphisms are homotopy classes of combings. We then prove that this category is triangulated, meaning that it has well-defined notions of kernels and cokernels, and that these can be used to define homology and cohomology groups of combings. Next, we explore various homotopy invariants of combings, including the number of teeth, the total space of the combing, and the fundamental group of the complement of the teeth. We show that all of these invariants can be computed using the above-mentioned homology and cohomology groups. 

In particular, we prove that the number of teeth is equal to the dimension of the kernel of a certain map from the homology group of the 3-manifold to its cohomology group, while the total space of the combing can be identified with the cokernel of another map between these groups. 

Finally, we show that the fundamental group of the complement of the teeth can be realized as a quotient of the fundamental group of the 3-manifold modulo a certain normal subgroup that encodes information about the combinatorics of the combing. 

Our results provide a new perspective on the study of 3-manifolds and their decompositions, and they have important implications for the understanding of topological and geometric structure of these spaces. They also demonstrate the power of our proposed approach to the study of homotopy invariants of combings, and pave the way for further investigations in this area.

- A recent approach, group sparsity [J. Bickel et al., 2009], seeks to impose sparsity on a set of variables (features) by using l 1 -penalties on groups of features instead of individual features. 

Group sparsity is particularly appealing for image processing where group sparsity can be imposed by enforcing that all pixels within a local neighborhood have similar nonzero values. Motivated by this, we generalize the concept of group sparsity to the problem of image segmentation and propose a novel framework for image segmentation based on group sparsity. 

In image segmentation, we aim to model the underlying piecewise constant (PWC) structure of the image and group lasso is shown to be able to handle a PWC image and reconstruct each constant pixel block given a collection of pixels that lie within the block. However, it is not able to model the overlapping and overlapped group structure needed for accurate segmentation. To capture the overlapping and overlapped structure in image segmentation tasks, our segmentation framework uses overlapped group lasso for image segmentation. A key ingredient of our approach is the efficient computation of overlapped group lasso. We propose an efficient algorithm for solving an overlapped group lasso problem. It is shown to converge to the optimal set of solutions. For any fixed point in the feasible region, convergence to an optimal solution is also guaranteed. 

Our segmentation approach is shown to have superior performance compared with recent approaches in image segmentation. 

Furthermore, the overlapped group lasso technique can be easily applied to a large class of signal/image processing problems: compressed sensing (MRI), matrix completion and principal component analysis (PCA). We have also performed simulations demonstrating the efficacy of our approach on segmentation-related tasks including image segmentation and de-noising. 

Our simulations also show how, in general, group sparsity techniques provide substantial improvement in performance compared to the corresponding non-overlapping approaches. 

We can use this for image compression as it enables the compressions of images to be even more effective.

> In this paper, we propose two strategies for the background context, including the whole image of the street environment or the surrounding vehicles, to assist vehicle image generation in scene-text spotting. In the rst strategy, we use the background context directly to guide the generation process of vehicles in a conditional adversarial network (CAN) framework. In this strategy, the relationship between the vehicles and the background is represented by their alignment via transformations. 

It generates the background context as reference images by feeding the whole scene text images. The generated vehicle image is obtained by sampling from the vehicle image classier conditioned on both images from the two modalities. 

In the second strategy, we use the background context to update the image generator via an adversarial learning procedure. 

After that, the generator will produce vehicles on top of the captured scene text images by itself. We nd that our proposed strategies boost the vehicle image generation quality not only when vehicles and the scene text images come from the same scene, but also from other scenes. 

It is not clear in this paper whether it is possible to generate images of scenes containing multiple vehicles driving on the same road...

Title: Sigma Point Belief Propagation

Abstract: This paper presents a new approach to belief propagation in Bayesian networks, based on the sigma point method. The sigma point method is a technique used in stochastic process control to estimate the state of the process, and it can be extended to belief propagation in Bayesian networks by using sigma points to represent the state of the network. The proposed approach uses sigma points to initialize the belief distribution and then iteratively updates the belief distribution using Bayesian rule and the sigma point method. The paper also presents a new algorithm for computing the probability of the next sigma point using Bayesian update rule and the sigma point method. 

The proposed approach is shown to be effective in estimating the posterior probability of the network parameters in a Bayesian model, as well as in computing the likelihood of the network parameters given new data. 

The paper concludes with a comparison with existing belief propagation methods, and the results show that the proposed method is computationally efficient and accurate.

The paper presents an automatic image pixel clustering algorithm based on the Mussels Wandering Optimization (MWO) algorithm. The proposed algorithm is designed to efficiently cluster pixels in an image based on their similarity in color and intensity. 

The MWO algorithm is used to optimize the clustering process by iteratively adjusting the cluster centers until convergence is achieved. 

The algorithm is tested on a variety of images and compared to other clustering algorithms. The results show that the proposed algorithm is effective in clustering pixels in an image and is more efficient than other clustering algorithms.

The paper presents a novel method for fast and accurate 3D medical image segmentation using data-swapping. 

The proposed method involves swapping the data from the source image with the target image to improve the segmentation accuracy. The data-swapping process is performed using a deep learning-based approach that involves training a neural network to predict the segmentation labels of the target image based on the source image. 

The proposed method is evaluated on a large dataset of 3D medical images and compared with state-of-the-art methods. The results show that the proposed method achieves faster and more accurate segmentation than the existing methods. The paper concludes that the data-swapping method is a promising approach for improving the accuracy and speed of 3D medical image segmentation.

> We propose a new method for image segmentation, which we call BoundarySqueeze. 

Our method is based on the observation that the boundary of an object is squeezed between the object and the background. 

We propose a new loss function that encourages the boundary to be squeezed between the object and the background. 

We show that our method can be trained end-to-end and can be applied to a wide range of segmentation tasks. We demonstrate that our method outperforms existing methods on several datasets. ## The Problem

The problem of image segmentation is to identify the boundaries of objects in an image. This is a challenging problem because the boundaries of objects are often not well-defined and can be difficult to distinguish from the background. 

## The Solution

We propose a new method for image segmentation, which we call BoundarySqueeze. Our method is based on the observation that the boundary of an object is squeezed between the object and the background. 

We propose a new loss function that encourages the boundary to be squeezed between the object and the background. 

We show that our method can be trained end-to-end and can be applied to a wide range of segmentation tasks. We demonstrate that our method outperforms existing methods on several datasets.

This study investigates the use of dilated convolutions in neural networks for left atrial segmentation in three-dimensional gadolinium enhanced-magnetic resonance imaging (3D GE-MRI). The aim is to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the segmentation process. 

We trained a deep learning model using 2D and 3D convolutional layers with different dilation rates, and evaluated its performance on a dataset of 30 patients. Our results show that incorporating dilated convolutions significantly improves the dice similarity coefficient compared to models without dilated convolutions. 

Additionally, we found that increasing the dilation rate leads to better segmentation outcomes. Overall, our approach provides an effective solution for left atrial segmentation in 3D GE-MRI utilizing state-of-the-art network architectures.

AttentionBoost is a method that enhances fully convolutional networks by learning what to attend to in an image. 

It uses a boosting approach to iteratively refine the network's attention map, leading to improved performance on various computer vision tasks. By incorporating attention mechanisms into the network, AttentionBoost allows for more efficient and accurate processing of visual information, making it a valuable tool for a range of applications in computer vision.

This research examines the relationship between supersymmetry and the topological properties of eigenfunctions in the context of the planar quantum pendulum. By analyzing the Schrdinger equation via semiclassical methods, we reveal that a hidden symmetry manifests itself through specific topologial structures within the wave functions associated with discrete energy levels. 

Our findings shed new light on the role of symmetries in shaping the spectral and dynamical features of nonlinear systems, providing insights into potential applications ranging from condensed matter physics to high-energy particle interactions.
