Ford has posted a record quarterly profit of $3.6bn, as strong finance arm performances offset falling car sales. 

The carmaker said it had benefited from higher prices and sales of new vehicles in the US. However, sales were hit by a lack of semiconductor computer chips, which are now only available at premium prices. The global shortage of chips has forced several carmakers to cut production, pushing up prices of both new and used cars. 

Ford chief executive Jim Farley said the company was " outperform" and focused on executing its plans. The strong financial performance "demonstrates once again the importance of our customer-focused operational execution and discipline," he said. 

Ford said it was now expecting its full-year pre-tax profits to be around $11.5bn to $12.5bn, up from $9bn to $10bn previously. 

The company also said it was generating stronger profit margins in every region, including China. It reported a 9% increase in revenue to $40.8bn for the three months to 30 September, compared with the same period in 2020. Ford's profit margin - a measure of how much profit it makes on each vehicle - rose to 13.1%, up from 10.2% a year earlier. The company said it had benefited from higher prices for its vehicles sold in North America and Europe, as well as increased sales in its credit division. It said it expects higher vehicle pricing to continue. 

However, it added that lower production volumes had affected its earnings by about $1.2bn. 

Car manufacturers have struggled with a shortage of semiconductors, which is driven by demand for electronic devices, including smartphones and laptops, during the pandemic. 

Last month, Ford was forced to cut production of its F-150 pickup truck - a best-selling vehicle in the US - because of the chip shortage. 

It also lowered its 2021 production forecast. Even though Ford has been hit by the chip shortage, like other carmakers, it has benefited from a broader surge in demand for cars and other vehicles during the pandemic. 

This has been driven by behaviour changes, including a shift towards using personal vehicles for transportation, as well as government stimulus programmes. While the chip shortage could linger into 2022, Ford has said it expects the semiconductor situation to get better by the second half of next year. "The semiconductor issue seems to be getting a little better," Ford's chief

The Labour party accused another Labour MP of allegedly involving himself in a plot to destabilise the party yesterday, as the embattled leader, Tony Blair, continued a series of meetings with Jewish community leaders aimed at calming their fears about his party. This came as Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, received a symbolic vote of confidence from his backbenchers yesterday, after suggestions that he had sought to undermine Mr Blair. 

One backbencher said information had been sent to all Labour MPs revealing that Mr Brown had telephoned Jack Dromey, the deputy general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, to demand that union funding be stopped from Labour MPs critical of the government.

China's biggest spirits maker, Kweichow Moutai, has signed a deal to boost its presence in Italy's booming wine market by distributing its products through Illva Saronno, one of the country's oldest and biggest liquor companies. The partnership, sealed on Thursday, gives Illva Saronno, producer of the Disaronno liqueur, distribution rights to Moutai's portfolio of baijiu, a distilled grain spirit usually made from sorghum. Illva said in a statement that the partnership aimed to "strengthen the presence of both companies on their respective home markets and to develop business opportunities in third countries". 

Moutai, whose fiery liquor is a favourite tipple of China's ruling Communist Party elite, has been looking to expand its global footprint. 

The company's lustre has dimmed somewhat in China in recent months as its flagship baijiu product has fallen out of favour with some younger consumers, who have turned to imported spirits such as Scotch whisky. 

However, it remains immensely popular in China, with its sales jumping 25% in the first half of 2022, and it is hoping to win over new consumers in Europe and elsewhere. Chinese drinks companies have been looking to expand abroad as domestic consumption slows and foreign sales of Chinese spirits, wine and beer are growing quickly. China's beer giant Budweiser Brewing Co Ltd, formed by the merger of Budweiser and local giant Tsingtao, has said it aims to become one of the world's top 10 beer companies within a decade. 

In July, Budweiser Brewing signed a deal with Coca-Cola Co's Costa coffee chain to roll out a line of coffee-flavoured drinks in China.

Martina Hingis gave hints of a brilliant career when she won the 1997 Wimbledon ladies' single title as an unseeded 17-year-old. 

The Swiss player claimed a total of five Grand Slam titles, 41 singles titles and a silver medal at the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney before retiring in 2002 aged 22. But on Thursday, the 41-year-old announced on social media that she will be making an unexpected return to tennis this month at the Billie Jean King Cup in Prague. Hingis will be representing Switzerland alongside world number 63 Jil Teichmann, Leonie Kng, and Joanne Zger. 

"It's time to put on my team jersey again," Hingis posted on Instagram. 

The iconic tennis player retired from the sport for a second time in November 2018 to focus on her family. Hingis has won three Grand Slam titles in women's doubles and six Grand Slam titles in mixed doubles.

The BBC can reveal the Premier League club paid him a total of 3,475,000, including 2,925,000 in deferred payments. The 775,000 interest-free loan - which has now been paid back - was the largest outstanding amount owed to any Premier League manager. Figures released by clubs for the period between 1 February 2021 and 31 January 2022 show Hague's earnings ranked behind only Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola, who earned 10,275,000. Hague was appointed as the Tigers' head coach in June 2021, replacing Grant McCann, who departed to take charge of Championship club Doncaster Rovers. 

Hull were then relegated from the Premier League, finishing bottom of the table in the 2020-21 season. 

The club earned 34,610,000 in total player wages during the period, including 6,870,000 in agent fees and have since been sold to Acun Ilicali for 37m.

Italy have plenty of reasons to feel confident as they prepare to face England in their Euro 2020 quarter-final on Saturday. 

Not only do they have a fully fit squad to choose from, but the way they swept aside a highly rated Belgian team 2-1 in the last 16 gives them a timely boost. 

And as manager Roberto Mancini pointed out on the eve of the game at Wembley, his team have another important weapon in their arsenal: the ability to hurt England from set pieces. It was, after all, a stunning free-kick from Leonardo Spinazzola that sparked them into life against Belgium, equalising just before half-time to silence a raucous crowd in Rome. 

And with England having a tendency to switch off at set plays  as shown in their nail-biting 2-1 win over Germany in the last 16  it is certainly a chink in their armoury that Italy plan to exploit. 

We have some weapons [from set pieces] and we have prepared well for them, because England are physically very strong and they often attack from set pieces, Mancini said. Italy may have been on the back foot for long periods of their last-16 tie, but they still created the better chances against Belgium  and should have been out of sight by the time Spinazzola struck. Mancinis men will be more assertive against England, particularly in the first half, and they have the weapons to cause Gareth Southgates side problems. Italy have plenty of height and physicality in their team, but it is the intelligence and movement of their centre-forward Ciro Immobile that is most impressive. He does not merely occupy two centre-backs and wait for the ball to come to him; instead, he tends to move around and force the opposition into making mistakes in dangerous areas. 

His header from Marco Verrattis cross was inches away from giving Italy the lead against Belgium, and he is due a goal at this tournament after working tirelessly in the opening group games. Immobile, who scored 36 goals in 38 games for Lazio last season, is likely to be Italys biggest threat on Saturday. 

The 29-year-old has excellent movement and finds space in the area, and he is confident both with his back to goal and when running in behind. He will look to get on the end of the many crosses

Rory McIlroy's second major triumph of the year continued after he secured his first major win since 2011 at the Honda Classic at Silverstone. 

After an opening nine holes that left him four strokes behind the pace set by Tiger Woods, he continued to edge the field to claim his first green jacket at the event. He later claimed another major win, adding a 300,000 prize money to his 9.1m from five majors. After a solid opening round, McIlroy shot 71 off the front of the field to finish T2 behind Woods who was five back. "The confidence was there in the first few rounds but I have to be proud of the way I finished - especially considering the circumstances," he said. 

"I felt like he and others were holding me back and that gave me a huge chip on my shoulder. I was on the back foot and had to really focus on my shot and my driving." The Scot, 31, has now won six and is now just five behind the record for the most majors secured in a career - all while averaging just 9.75 over 60 starts. In a year when McIlroy has claimed a number of important victories - including his first WGC-Cadillac Championship victory last February - it came as a surprise when he opted to back up the victory with another. 

A move to a course that had little chance of producing a win didn't help either - but his confidence was on the rise thanks to a win between two World Golf Championships Tournaments. 

And after another solid start he seemed to be making a dent in the long-term plan of Woods to make a comeback. 

At one stage it looked as though the US Open champion was poised to claim his 14th major title before an early mishit at the 11th added to his woes. 

There was some hope the course at Riviera Country Club, in Florida, had improved after some encouraging signs on 18, but McIlroy was in no-man's land with the shot on 19 and, to his credit, he didn't let go of hope at that point. By the middle of the last week McIlroy became the fastest player ever to win at seven straight Majors

Diane Abbott MP today said she had no time for 'bullies' who were throwing 'the politics of hate in my face'. Mrs Abbott, the shadow Secretary of State for International Development, made her remarks during the weekly Shadow Cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street. 

She also told leaders that she could not ignore attacks on Muslims and those from ethnic minorities to help build stronger social cohesion within the United Kingdom.

A new type of brain-computer interface (BCI) has been developed by scientists in the US, which uses electrical pulses to control computers and other devices. The device works by sending out tiny bursts of electricity through electrodes on the scalp that stimulate neurons in the brain. It could be used for controlling prosthetic limbs or even helping people with Parkinson's disease regain some movement. 

Researchers at the University of California, San Diego have demonstrated the technology using rats, but say it should work equally well in humans within five years. "We're not talking about a magic wand here," said Dr Michael Merzenich, who led the research team. 

"This is something you can put on your head." 

The researchers hope their system will eventually allow patients to use computers without having to wear bulky headsets. 

They are also working on ways to make the BCI more comfortable for users. 

In addition to being able to control computers, this BCI would also be useful for treating Parkinson's Disease. 

This is because the disease causes the loss of dopamine receptors in the brain, which leads to tremors and rigidity. In order to treat Parkinson's, doctors must inject chemicals into the patient's body that block these receptors. However, if the drug is administered too early, it may cause side effects such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. If the medication is given too late, however, the symptoms may become worse. 

If the BCI were to be implanted under the skin, it would be much easier to administer the drugs. Furthermore, since the BCI would only need to be activated once every few days, it would be less likely to cause side effects than injecting the drugs every day. 

However, there are still many questions surrounding this BCI. For example, how long does the stimulation last? How do the signals travel between the brain and the electrode caps? What happens when the signal reaches the cap? 

And what happens if the signal is interrupted? 

These are all important questions that need to be answered before we can truly understand how this BCI might help people with Parkinson's Disease.

Lufthansa expects this year to increase profitability, the company's board and management said Tuesday on a conference call with analysts. 

Budget airline giant Lufthansa said Tuesday it expected a return to profit this year, at least in part due to a new business model including new routes and increased demand for its low-cost airline and premium seats over the short term. 

Revenue from all products for the first quarter rose to 4.07 billion from 44.3 million in the year-ago period. 

Lufthansa had an operating profit of 1.4 billion, down from 1.66 billion in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell as forecast to 41 billion. 

"In terms of revenue, revenue from ticket operations dropped 10% because of lower demand from leisure travelers and new flights," said Peter Mueller from Deutsche Bank. 

He said that new business models, such as Lufthansa premium product offering, were driving down the number of fares booked into the airport. "This business model also has caused a decline in the number of passenger boardings [on the Lufthansa network] and a corresponding drop in revenue," he said. Revenue from all airlines fell 3% to 43.3 billion, with the decline driven mostly by passenger boardings, the largest component, the airline said. The airline forecast a 3.7% drop in earnings per share to 1.45 per share in the third quarter from 1.5 per share in the same period last year, a figure that analysts said was far less optimistic than the 3.9% rate suggested by Lufthansa executives. 

Analysts expect the airline to see a turnaround in passenger volumes and profits after years of losses and falling revenues. The airline has spent heavily on building its own fleet and is expanding its route network, especially on long-haul routes, which analysts say will help it recover profit lost long ago. But Lufthansa is also having the effect of eroding its competitors' profits in the short term. "We are starting to see Lufthansa's competitors also looking to reduce their prices which is adding to their cost pressure," said Mueller.

The earnings of Foreign Secretary William Hague have been revealed in the register of MPs' interests. The list shows he received 140,000 for writing a book about his time as leader of the Conservative Party. 

He also got 22,916 for after-dinner speeches and 15,000 for two articles for the Daily Telegraph. The list shows he received 140,000 for writing a book about his time as leader of the Conservative Party. 

He also got 22,916 for after-dinner speeches and 15,000 for two articles for the Daily Telegraph.

Italian drinks group Illva Saronno is to buy a majority stake in a Chinese wine producer as it looks to tap into the country's growing appetite for the tipple. 

The maker of the popular Disaronno liqueur said it would pay 20m ($22.6m; 14.6m) for a 51% stake in Great Wall. The deal comes as China's wine market is forecast to grow by a fifth this year. Illva said the move would help it become a "leading player" in the Chinese market. The company, which also owns the Martini vermouth brand, said it would invest a further 10m in Great Wall over the next three years. "This is a strategic investment for Illva in one of the most interesting and fastest-growing markets in the world," said chief executive Paolo Marchesini. 

"It will enable us to become a leading player in the premium segment of the Chinese wine market." 

Great Wall, which is based in Shandong province in eastern China, produces about 10m bottles of wine a year. Its wines are currently sold in more than 20 countries, including the US, Canada, Australia and Japan. 

The deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

The Oscar-nominated actor Michael J Fox is backing plans for a new theatre in the town where he grew up. 

The Back to the Future star has donated money to the fundraising campaign for the proposed Michael J Fox Theatre in Burnaby, British Columbia. The 1,200-seat venue would stage everything from musicals to comedy shows. Fox, who was born in Edmonton, Alberta, but moved to Burnaby as a child, said the theatre would be a "great asset" to the community. "I have very fond memories of growing up in Burnaby and attending shows at the old Burnaby Senior Secondary School auditorium," he said in a statement. 

"A new theatre would be a great asset for the entire community." 

The project is expected to cost C$60m (34m) and construction could begin as early as next year.

The future of ballet in the UK is under threat, a group of dancers has warned. 

The dancers, who are all members of the Royal Ballet, say the art form is in decline and that there are not enough opportunities for young dancers to progress. 

In a letter to the Times newspaper, they say the UK is "losing its position as a world leader in ballet". The dancers say the government should do more to support ballet and invest in the art form. The letter has been signed by 26 dancers, including former Royal Ballet principal dancer Tamara Rojo and current first soloist Francesca Hayward. 

The dancers say ballet is "facing an existential crisis" and that the art form is "in decline". They say there are not enough opportunities for young dancers to progress and that the government should do more to support ballet. The letter has been sent to the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, as well as the Arts Council England.

Car production at Ford's European operations has fallen by almost a quarter this year, but the US giant says it is still on track to make a profit. Ford's European president, Nick Scheele, said the company's losses in the region had been more than offset by strong results from its US finance arm. "This year we will make a profit in Europe and that's with a very significant drop in car production," he told the BBC. "Last year we lost $254m (130m) in Europe. 

This year we will make a profit. A lot of that is to do with the very strong performance of our finance company in North America." 

Ford's US finance business has been helped by low interest rates, which have allowed it to offer cheap loans to buyers. 

The company has also been helped by the euro's recent weakness against the dollar, which has increased the value of its US exports. Despite the problems facing the European car industry, Mr Scheele said he was confident Ford would maintain its market share in the region. 

"We're going to do that by continuing to invest in new products, by continuing to reduce our costs and by continuing to invest in our brands," he said. 

"We think we've got the right strategy in place and we're beginning to see the results of that."

Former UK Foreign Secretary, William Hague, has reportedly earned a six-figure sum from his various roles outside of politics, according to recently released financial documents. 

The documents reveal that Mr Hague has been earning substantial amounts from his work as a speaker, author, and consultant. His earnings from these roles are in addition to his parliamentary pension, which he receives following his service as an MP and cabinet minister. 

Mr Hague, who served as the leader of the Conservative Party from 1997 to 2001 and as Foreign Secretary from 2010 to 2014, has been a prominent figure in British politics for several decades. Since stepping down from his role as Foreign Secretary, he has taken on a number of lucrative roles in the private sector. The financial documents show that Mr Hague has earned over 800,000 from his work as a speaker alone. 

He is represented by the Washington Speakers Bureau, which also represents other high-profile figures such as former US Secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, and former Prime Minister, Tony Blair. 

In addition to his speaking engagements, Mr Hague has also earned significant sums from his work as an author. His books, which include histories of William Pitt the Younger and William Wilberforce, have been well received and have added to his earnings. 

Furthermore, Mr Hague has also worked as a consultant for several major companies. 

His consultancy work has reportedly earned him a further six-figure sum. The release of these financial documents has led to some criticism of Mr Hague. Critics argue that it is inappropriate for former politicians to earn such large sums from private sector work, particularly when they continue to receive a parliamentary pension. However, supporters of Mr Hague argue that he is entitled to pursue a career outside of politics and that his earnings reflect his skills and experience. 

Mr Hague has not commented on the release of the financial documents.

Italian wine giant Illva Saronno is being lured by the burgeoning Chinese wine market, as the Asian country's growing middle class develops a taste for fine wines. 

Illva Saronno, known for producing Disaronno and Tia Maria, is considering expanding its operations into China, a move that could potentially boost its global sales and brand recognition. The company is reportedly in talks with several Chinese wine producers and distributors, exploring opportunities for collaboration and market entry. 

China's wine market has been growing rapidly over the past decade, driven by a rising middle class with increasing disposable income and a growing appreciation for Western lifestyle and products. 

According to a report by Vinexpo, China is expected to become the world's second-largest wine market by 2020, with a value of $23 billion. 

Illva's interest in China comes as no surprise, given the potential for growth. The company, which has a strong presence in Europe and North America, has been looking to expand its global footprint. 

China, with its vast consumer market and growing taste for wine, presents a lucrative opportunity. 

However, entering the Chinese market is not without challenges. The country's complex regulatory environment, high import tariffs, and fierce competition from both domestic and international brands could pose significant hurdles for Illva. Moreover, Chinese consumers' wine preferences are still evolving, and it remains to be seen whether they will develop a taste for Illva's offerings. 

Despite these challenges, Illva seems undeterred. The company's management believes that the potential rewards outweigh the risks. 

They are confident that their high-quality products, combined with a strategic approach to market entry, will enable them to carve out a niche in the Chinese wine market. Illva's move towards China is reflective of a broader trend in the global wine industry. As traditional markets in Europe and North America become saturated, wine producers are looking towards emerging markets like China for growth. If successful, Illva's foray into China could pave the way for other Western wine producers to follow suit. 

The company has not yet released a timeline for its potential expansion into China. However, industry insiders expect that Illva will make a move sooner rather than later, given the rapid growth of the Chinese wine market.

Acclaimed film star, Fox, has officially announced a new venture into the world of theatre. 

The beloved silver screen icon has become the latest Tinseltown resident to take an interest in local theatre, backing a bid to develop premium theatre space in London. In an effort to support the performing arts and champion live theatre, Fox has joined a consortium that aims to renovate and re-purpose an old, historic auditorium in the heart of London's West End. 

The proposal also includes plans for an acting academy for budding performers. 

Speaking at a recent press conference held at the theatre site, Fox called the project a 'real labour of love'. "Theatre is where most actors get their start and remains a unique platform for storytelling. With this project, I hope to give something back to the industry that has given me so much." Born into the business, Fox made a name on the big screen with a repertoire of highly acclaimed performances in a career spanning three decades. However, the star's roots can be traced back to the theatre, making this passion project a significant milestone in their illustrious career. 

Support for the project has poured in from prominent members of the cultural sector, along with a healthy response from fans. 

Director Danny Boyle described the plans as a terrific way to breathe new life into classic theatre productions and provide a kick-start to burgeoning talents.

While details surrounding the theatres planned inaugural production remain under wraps, the project will undoubtedly mark a significant moment for the industry. In recent years, several high-profile film actors have made successful transitions to the theatre, and Fox's involvement could lead to more Hollywood names treading the boards. Although the pandemic has inflicted considerably harsh setbacks on theatres worldwide, the sector has demonstrated resilience in the face of adversity. Initiatives like Fox's theatre bid are essential in helping the industry recover and continue contributing significantly to the UKs cultural landscape. 

The London Theatre's new revival backed by Fox has projected an opening date for its inaugural production sometime in 2022, marking the start of an exciting and transformative chapter for London's West End. 

With a film star like Fox leading the way, the future of British theatre is looking more radiant than ever.

Concerns are growing over the future of ballet, as the global pandemic continues to disrupt the performing arts industry. Ballet companies worldwide are grappling with significant financial losses, cancelled performances, and the challenge of maintaining rigorous training regimes amidst social distancing measures. 

The Royal Ballet, one of the world's leading ballet companies, has reported a significant drop in revenue due to the cancellation of performances. 

The company, like many others, has been forced to furlough staff and dancers, raising concerns about the long-term impact on the industry. "The pandemic has hit us hard," said Kevin O'Hare, Director of The Royal Ballet. 

"We've lost millions in revenue, and we're still unsure when we'll be able to perform again. 

It's a worrying time for everyone involved in ballet." 

The impact is not just financial. The physical demands of ballet require dancers to maintain a high level of fitness and flexibility. With training facilities closed and classes moved online, many dancers are struggling to maintain their physical condition. "Dancing at home is not the same," said Maria, a dancer with the English National Ballet. "We don't have the space or the right flooring. It's hard to keep up the same level of intensity." The pandemic has also disrupted the career progression of many young dancers. Ballet schools have been closed, auditions cancelled, and opportunities for young dancers to gain stage experience have been severely limited. 

"The future of ballet is at risk," said Dame Darcey Bussell, former Principal of The Royal Ballet. 

"We need to find ways to support our dancers, financially and emotionally, and ensure that the art form survives this crisis." 

There are some signs of hope, however. Many ballet companies have moved performances online, reaching new audiences and generating some revenue. 

The Royal Ballet's online performance of "The Nutcracker" was viewed by over a million people worldwide. "We're adapting and innovating," said O'Hare. 

"We're finding new ways to reach our audiences and keep ballet alive." 

Despite these efforts, the future of ballet remains uncertain. As the pandemic continues, the industry will need to find new ways to survive and thrive in a world where live performances may not be possible for some time. 

"We're in uncharted territory," said Bussell. 

"But ballet has survived wars, recessions, and other crises. We're resilient, and we'll find a way through this."

In an unexpected turn of events, Ford Motor Company's profits are currently being driven by its finance division rather than its core automobile manufacturing segment. 

According to the most recent fiscal report, the automotive giant is reaping significant earnings from its Ford credit unit. 

Amidst the global chip shortage affecting auto industry production, Ford's traditional source of profit  the sale of vehicles  has encountered major setbacks. However, the Ford Motor Credit Company's performance has been surging, offering a buffer against some of the strain. 

The Ford credit arm provides financing products for dealers and buyers, such as wholesale inventory financing and retail installment sale contracts for new and used vehicles. 

An upswing in the used cars market, induced by limited new car availability, has directly benefited this segment of their business. 

Additionally, the low interest rates over the past year have encouraged auto financing, producing windfalls for the division. 

Ford's most recent quarterly report revealed that the finance division made a gain of $1.6 billion in pre-tax profit, making a substantial contribution to the overall earnings. This is a stark contrast to the minor profit of $533 million that the automotive division reported for the same period. 

Even though the company's structure is weighted towards vehicle manufacturing, the profitability of its finance division is not unusual in the auto industry. Typically, car manufacturers' financing units provide a consistent revenue stream, sometimes yielding bigger profit margins than the sale of the cars themselves. "On one hand, the numbers are illustrating the financial pressures that Ford and other automakers are dealing with right now due to supply chain issues," says Jessica Caldwell, an analyst at Edmunds.com. 

"However, they also highlight the strategic benefits of having diverse revenue sources." Ford's executives seem to agree with this viewpoint. In a statement, CFO John Lawler said, "Our Ford Credit team continues to perform exceptionally well, including managing through the ongoing used vehicle pricing environment." Nonetheless, the profit report is a mixed blessing for Ford as it has to manage a delicate balance, taking into consideration the global car market upheaval and their finance department performance. 

The ongoing semiconductor chip shortage isn't expected to be resolved soon, posing an operational challenge to Ford and other manufacturers. In conclusion, while Ford's automobile division is under considerable strain due to the global chip crisis, the company's profitability is currently being driven by its finance arm, a slice of overall enterprise that's proving to be a silver lining in these challenging times. This trend further shines a spotlight on the importance of diverse revenue streams within integrated business models.

A thrilling adventure story about a group of explorers who embark on a perilous journey through uncharted terrain has won top honors at this year's prestigious Adventure Awards ceremony. The book, titled "The Unmapped Path," took home the coveted Golden Compass award for Best Adventure Story, beating out stiff competition from a field of talented authors and adventurers. The story follows a team of four friends who set out to explore a remote and dangerous region of the world, pushing themselves to their limits as they face treacherous landscapes, harsh weather conditions, and other obstacles along the way. 

The author, Alexandra Stewart, said she was thrilled to receive the award and praised her fellow nominees for their inspiring tales of adventure. 

"I am truly humbled to have received this honor among such an impressive group of finalists," Stewart said in her acceptance speech. "My hope is that 'The Unmapped Path' will inspire readers to seek out new experiences and challenges, and to never stop exploring." 

Stewart, who has been an avid adventurer herself for many years, drew on her own experiences traveling through rugged environments to create the story. She spent months researching and preparing before embarking on the expedition that would become the basis for her award-winning book. 

The annual Adventure Awards celebrate the best in adventure writing, filmmaking, and photography, with winners chosen by a panel of experts in each category. The awards are highly regarded within the adventure community and are seen as a benchmark of excellence in outdoor pursuits. 

In addition to the top prize for Best Adventure Story, "The Unmapped Path" also took home awards for Best Photography and Best Film, making it a clean sweep for the book in the three most prestigious categories. Other notable winners at this year's Adventure Awards included a documentary about climbing Mount Everest without oxygen, which won Best Documentary, and a collection of photographs showcasing life in some of the world's most extreme environments, which won Best Portfolio.

Scotland head coach Gregor Townsend has named his 31-man squad for next month's Six Nations campaign, with Glasgow Warriors prop Zander Fagerson and Edinburgh back row Jamie Ritchie returning after injury layoffs. 

Fagerson missed last year's tournament through injury while Ritchie was ruled out by concussion in November. Glasgow centre Nick Grigg also makes the cut despite being dropped for their Champions Cup defeat against Leinster on Saturday. 

The Scots open their campaign at home to Italy on Sunday, 2 February (kick off 14:15 GMT). Townsend said: "We have selected a strong group that we believe can challenge for silverware this season."

The judge overseeing the retrial of John Warboys for a 2003 murder has apologised after comments made earlier. Mr Justice Bean said a juror had been dismissed after being found not to have told the truth during questioning. 

He said he needed to put on record "what appears to have been a misunderstanding" for a transcript of comments he made. 

A Court of Appeal is hearing the case of Woolf, the youngest of Warboys' seven victims. 

Mr Justice Bean had earlier made a reference to her "witnesses" - which is what a juror is technically called. 

'Confusion'

He said he had not been referring to a witness who had given evidence in court, but a female friend of 26-year-old Woolf, who was with her at the time she died. "I need to set the record straight: there is confusion here, in part because the reference I made during an in-court-whisper, about the 'witness', may have been misunderstood, and in part because I made a reference to her without going into detail and, in retrospect, I should have." 

Mr Justice Bean told jurors he was sorry if his words had caused any confusion. "I wanted to be very clear about this so I am making the point now and hope that it will clear the air," he said. 'Disgusted'

Woolf died in 2003 when she was run over by Warboys at the foot of his drive in Gateshead. A jury had earlier failed to convict Warboys over her death and a retrial was ordered. 

The 61-year-old is also accused of murdering two other women - Lindsay Owen-Jones, 22, from West London, and Ann McDonnal, another 22-year-old whose body has never been found.

Budget supercar

> The Budget Aston Martin has taken on the might of Porsche, as the 1959 Aston Martin DB4GT continues its fight for survival at a Bonhams sale in Marbella, Spain. The DB4GT is one of only 75 made, and was once part of Aston Martin chairman David Brown's private collection. >
> The ultra-rare Aston will be accompanied by another classic DB4GT, at Bonhams' Marbella auction on Sunday. 

Both cars have less than 600 miles and were purchased by British businessman David Duckham when the original owner decided to sell them during the late 1980s. It's understood that the cars were bought specifically for the current owner who has spent the best part of 25 years restoring them to their original glory. 

>
> But the cars are expected to go for under their original price. The DB4GT, which is part of the original owner's family collection and is likely to have been one of the last cars built, is estimated to fetch in the region of 2.3m to 2.7m (US$3m to US$3.47m), while the other car, a factory competition car believed to have been prepared in the 1960s by Aston Martin's own competition department, is estimated to make between 1m (US$1.45m) and 1.3m. 

>
>
>
> Aside from the DB4 GTs, a 1962 Fiat Dino Spyder is expected to make between 2m and 3m (US$2.8m and US$3.54m), while a 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300 S Cabriolet A has a pre-sale estimate of between 1m (US$1.4m) and 1.5m.

Two US men have been found guilty in separate cases for running websites that allowed users to illegally download music and films, prosecutors say. Jury members took less than two hours to convict 28-year-old Eric McGowan on charges including conspiracy to commit copyright infringement. He ran the site TVShack.net which offered links to illegal copies of movies and television shows. In another case, a jury also found 30-year-old Jason Goldman guilty of similar offences. 

He operated the website MovieTiger.com. Both defendants face up to five years in prison when they are sentenced later this year. 

The verdicts were announced by the US Department of Justice (DoJ) after both trials concluded at federal courts in New York City. 

Mr McGowan was accused of operating TVShack.net between January 2005 and March 2010. 

It had more than one million registered users who could access content via BitTorrent file sharing software. Prosecutors said he earned $47,000 (30,000) through advertising revenue during his time as administrator of the site. 

They added that Mr McGowan's actions caused losses of about $6m to film studios and other rights holders. 

Meanwhile, Mr Goldman was charged with running MovieTiger.com - a site offering links to unauthorised versions of Hollywood blockbusters such as Avatar and Transformers. It was estimated that the site generated more than $90,000 in ad revenues over its lifetime.

Microsoft has announced that it will be offering a swap program to users who have purchased pirated copies of Windows XP. The program, which is available until June 30th, allows eligible customers to exchange their unlicensed copy of Windows XP for a legitimate one at no additional cost. To qualify for the program, users must provide proof of purchase of the pirated version of Windows XP and meet certain eligibility requirements. 

Those who are accepted into the program will receive a new license key for a legal copy of Windows XP, as well as access to any necessary updates and support. Microsoft's decision to launch this program comes in response to concerns about the widespread use of pirated software, which can lead to security vulnerabilities and other issues. 

By providing an easy way for users to switch to a legitimate version of the operating system, Microsoft hopes to help protect both its own business interests and the broader technology community.

A UK-based property company is facing legal action in Venezuela over its ownership of thousands of acres of land, following allegations that it has failed to pay taxes and violated local laws. The dispute centres on a 100,000 hectare estate owned by the British firm, which was acquired from the government in the early 2000s as part of a joint venture with a local partner. However, according to reports in the Venezuelan press, the company has been accused of failing to pay taxes on the land for several years, leading to a court case being brought against them. 

In addition to tax issues, there are also claims that the company has breached environmental regulations and failed to provide adequate compensation to indigenous communities living near the estate. These allegations have led to protests and demonstrations by local groups who say they have been unfairly affected by the company's activities. 

The UK government has been contacted by both sides in the dispute, with representatives from the property company denying any wrongdoing and insisting that they are working closely with the Venezuelan authorities to resolve the issue. 

The Foreign Office has said that it is monitoring the situation closely and providing support to British nationals involved in the case.

Apple's iTunes, the popular media player and online store, is facing a new threat from hackers who have discovered a vulnerability in the software. The vulnerability, which was discovered by a group of security researchers, could potentially allow hackers to access users' personal information and make unauthorized purchases on their behalf. 

The vulnerability, which has been assigned a severity rating of "high," affects all versions of iTunes, including the latest version, 12.5.1. 

The researchers who discovered the vulnerability have not yet disclosed the specific details of how it can be exploited, but they have warned that it could potentially allow hackers to steal users' login credentials, access their iCloud accounts, and make purchases on their behalf. Apple has not yet released a patch to fix the vulnerability, but the company has said that it is working on a fix and will release it as soon as possible. 

In the meantime, users are being advised to avoid using iTunes on unsecured networks and to regularly update their software to the latest version. 

The discovery of the vulnerability comes at a time when Apple is facing increased scrutiny over its security practices. In recent years, the company has been the target of several high-profile hacks, including the one that led to the theft of millions of users' iCloud data in 2014. Apple has since implemented a number of security measures to improve the security of its products and services, but the latest vulnerability in iTunes highlights the ongoing challenges of keeping software secure in the face of increasingly sophisticated attacks.

Portsmouth manager Harry Redknapp is poised to accept an offer to move south to Portsmouth manager Harry Redknapp is poised to accept an offer to move south to become coach of the France squad. 

French Football Federation boss Jean-Pierre Escalettes told BBC Radio Solent that Redknapp would be his next coach
Redknapp has previously said he is prepared to go to the World Cup in South Africa in June even if he is replacing the axed Raymond Domenech
"I would love to work with France - it is a fantastic challenge," said Redknapp. "I am a French speaker: I played seven years in France and I watched the game in detail. 

If it looks as if I can be of any use to France I will go there." 

A French Football Federation spokesman in Paris was unable to confirm the appointment but BBC Radio Solent has learned that Redknapp has already signed a two-year contract - albeit privately - with the Federation. 

He added: "I have the right to talk to anybody - and Jean-Pierre is not an outsider." Redknapp was also contacted by Tottenham Hotspur and said he would like to manage his old club again in the future. "I would like a new job if that was Portsmouth, Tottenham, or France," he said. "I would look at Portsmouth, Tottenham or France in that order." Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric has previously said he will not entertain offers for Redknapp, who is wanted by West Ham. 

Mandaric has denied speculation he is considering an approach for West Ham boss Gianfranco Zola, although it is believed former Hammers manager Alan Curbishley would be his choice.

However, Portsmouth chairman Milan Mandaric has so far blocked any attempt to poach Redknapp, who would be keen to work under his former Portsmouth team-mate Zola at Upton Park. British actors and filmmakers have been shut out of the major categories at this year's Oscars, despite a strong showing in the nominations. The Academy Awards, which celebrate the best in film, are widely regarded as the most prestigious in the industry. 

But this year, none of the British actors or films nominated in the major categories - including best picture, best director, and best actor and actress - took home the top prize. 

This comes after a strong showing for British talent in previous years, with actors such as Emma Stone and Rami Malek winning best actress and best actor awards in 2019 and 2018, respectively. The lack of recognition for British talent has been met with disappointment by industry insiders and fans alike, who had hoped to see more representation for the country's thriving film scene. Despite the snub, many in the industry remain optimistic about the future of British cinema and the potential for future nominations and wins at the Oscars and other major awards shows.

The release of an upcoming Bollywood film depicting the 2008 Mumbai attacks has been delayed amid concerns over its timing and potential to cause offence. 'Taal' was set to premiere on January 24th, but production studio Reliance Entertainment announced yesterday that it would be pushed back indefinitely after receiving feedback from various stakeholders, including families of victims who were killed in the terrorist attack. 

While no specific reason for the delay was provided, sources close to the production claimed that several crew members received death threats due to the controversy surrounding the project. The decision comes just weeks after India's Union Government rejected permission for the film's screening asserting that it may disturb harmony among different sections of society. 

In 2015, director Gauri Shinde defended her choice to make the film by stating that she wanted to bring attention to stories often overlooked during such tragic events  those of ordinary people trying to survive amidst chaos. However, critics argue that dramatizing suchsensitive topics without proper sensitization could potentially reignite old wounds or aggravate existing tensions between communities in bothIndiaandPakistan. Despite ongoing debates around appropriateness and sensitivity towards survivors and relatives, lead actor AliaBhatt expressedhersupportforthefilm,arguingthatitwas"crucialtohonor themoments insidethe story." 

While there isno officialnew dateforshortly thereafter with further updates expected soonthe resumptionof Taal, this unexpecteddevelopment seems tomove ahead as discussionsaround censorshipcontinue within theeager industry.

Home Secretary Charles Clarke is facing an unprecedented revolt from his own party over plans to introduce identity cards, with reports suggesting that up to 40 Labour MPs could vote against the proposals when they are debated in Parliament next week. The government's proposal for compulsory national identification cards has been widely criticised by civil liberties groups and opposition parties as an invasion of privacy and an expensive waste of time. 

However, it was thought that Mr Clarke had managed to win round many sceptical colleagues through a series of concessions designed to address their concerns. 

But according to The Sunday Times, senior ministers have warned that between 30 and 40 Labour backbenchers remain opposed to the plan despite these changes, which include dropping plans for a central database holding all the information on card holders. A defeat in Tuesday's Commons debate would be a major blow to Mr Clarke personally - who staked much of his reputation on getting the scheme passed - and also threaten to undermine Prime Minister Tony Blair's authority within his own party. However, Downing Street sources insisted yesterday that there were no plans to drop or water down the contentious measure, despite growing pressure from opponents both inside and outside parliament.

Former Prime Minister Tony Blair has stressed the importance of focusing on economic prosperity and social justice in order to create a more equal society. In a speech at the annual Fabian Society conference, Mr Blair said that while the Labour Party had achieved much in government, there was still much work to be done to ensure that everyone had the opportunity to succeed. He called for a renewed focus on education and training, as well as measures to tackle poverty and inequality. 

"We need to be in no doubt that the key to creating a more equal society is economic prosperity," he said. 

"But prosperity alone is not enough. We also need to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to share in that prosperity and that we tackle the deep-seated social injustices that persist in our society." 

Mr Blair, who led Labour to three election victories between 1997 and 2005, said that the party needed to be "ambitious and radical" in its policies. 

"We cannot be content with tinkering around the edges," he said. "We need to be bold and visionary in our approach, and to set out a clear and compelling alternative to the Conservatives' narrow and divisive vision of society."

In the House of Fortune, secrets lie,
Whispers of destiny, floating high. A tapestry woven with threads of fate,
Where dreams and desires congregate. Within these walls, a mystical dance,
Where chance and luck intertwine, enhance. 

Fortune's hand, a fickle guide,
Leading some to glory, others to hide. The House of Fortune, a realm untamed,
Where destinies are forged, unnamed. A roulette wheel spins, destiny's game,
As souls seek fortune, fame, and acclaim. 

Here, the gambler's heart beats fast,
As hopes and dreams are cast. 

Cards are dealt, dice are thrown,
In this house, the unknown is known. But beware, for fortune can deceive,
A fleeting mistress, quick to leave. 

In the House of Fortune, one must be wise,
For every gain, there's a sacrifice. 

Yet, amidst the uncertainty and strife,
There's a glimmer of hope, a chance at life. 

For in this house, where fortunes are won,
There's a possibility for everyone. So step inside, take a chance,
Embrace the chaos, the circumstance. For in the House of Fortune, you may find,
A destiny that's uniquely designed.

When mighty Marlborough leads his warlike bands,
The fate of kingdoms trembles in his hands. 

His veteran troops, with fame and honour known,
Have made the proudest enemy to own
That skill and valour here united reign,
And Europe owns this hero's glorious reign. Behold him now, in triumphs great and high,
Where victory attends him in the sky. Exalted on the wings of fame, he soars,
And spreads his conquering banners on distant shores. 

No danger daunts him, no fatigue retards
The progress of his arms, his brave regards. 

Through fields of death, where loud the cannons roar,
He fearless leads the charge, and gains the shore. With boldness, wisdom, and with strength untired,
He drives opposing hosts, with blood admired. 

No industry prevails, nor art can save,
Where Marlborough commands, he conquers or he leaves. 

To grateful nations, he transmits their laws,
And gladly yields them from oppression's cause. The slave, released, now knows his native rights,
And tastes the sweets of freedom's fair delights. 

The injured Thames, long groaning in alarms,
Now sees the ravished nymphs restored to arms. 

O thou, great Marlborough, whose exalted name
Shines like a meteor in the lists of fame,
Thy deeds shall fill the sounding trump of fate,
And thy own words shall best recite thy state. Thy monuments, renowned through future days,
Shall for thy martial worth transmit thy praise. Thy country's love, thy prince's just regard,
Shall prove the blessings of a great reward. Long may thy life and glory still endure,
And showers of blessings on thy head secure. 

May victory and honour still attend
Thy warlike steps, thy sacred person defend. While thankful millions sing thy great success,
And hail thee, Marlborough, with joy and happiness.

In step with one another, side by side,
We wander through the world, our spirits tied. 

Through fields of green and forests deep,
Our souls entwined, our secrets we keep. Hand in hand, we face the unknown,
Together we conquer, we're not alone. 

Through stormy weather and darkest night,
Our love shines bright, a guiding light. 

With every step, our bond grows strong,
In harmony we move, where we belong. Through laughter and tears, we share it all,
Our hearts connected, never to fall. Through winding paths and mountains high,
We journey on, beneath the open sky. 

With every stride, we find our way,
Together we walk, come what may. Through life's twists and turns, we navigate,
Our love unwavering, never to abate. 

With every footfall, we leave a mark,
Walking together, through light and dark. In sync we move, our rhythm in tune,
Our love a melody, beneath the moon. Through valleys low and peaks so high,
We walk together, you and I.

Within the realms of memory we find
A space reserved for those who've passed away. 

Their presence still remains, their spirits bind
Us in their love, forever and a day. 

These sonnets penned, a tribute to their souls,
Capture the essence of their timeless grace. Their laughter, warmth, and love our hearts console,
As tears are shed for them in this embrace. 

Gone from this mortal realm, they still reside. Their spirit lingers, whispering on the breeze. In dreams they visit, close by our side,
Reminding us of all the joy they seize. Within our thoughts and hearts forever more,
Their memory lives on, we can't ignore.

Though fickle is the path we tread,
And serendipity at times feels lost,
Still as the stars our course is set,
Entwined in destiny's deliberate hand. No matter how we strive and chase,
The universe its plans will lay,
We may stumble and we may fall,
But purpose whispers through it all. For in the tapestry woven deep,
Fate's gentle thread finds its way,
Guiding us to encounters profound,
Where love and longing are bound. Across the oceans, mountains high,
Through the darkest nights we sigh,
Destiny awaits with open arms,
An eternal dance of wondrous charms. 

In moments unexpected, surreal,
Our lives connected in a cosmic reel,
Serendipity's sweet smile unfurls,
Uniting souls, two halves of a whole. 

With every heartbeat, breath we take,
Our destinies align, no choice to make,
For intertwined are our paths divine,
Bound together, by life's grand design.

Sure I'm absolved your Grace of all blame
In sailing hence to Cadiz:
But as your friend, I beg you'll hear me
Just for a minute. 

When this unlucky fleet was order'd
To sail for the south,
To join our cousins, men of honour,
That's when our troubles began. 

Barely out of port we met 'em
In ev'ry direction
Of all your army, which I told ye
From the beginning. 

'Twas more than just a pleasure
To welcome Prince George
And all your gallant army,
Which land'd them here,
And though inclined to heaviness
They'd keep us all from harm. They'd boast about the French fleet
Being chased to the shore,
And how they'd captured cities
Both seaports and border towns,
Burnt docks and warehouses
And scatter'dplots of corn. 

And thus they'd keep us cheerful
Until we'd anchor'd here,
Where we found five French frigates
Ahead of us, it seem'd clear. 

With one sail in the distance,
Which they made haste to chase,
And we were order'd after 'em
Not to lag behind. 

It was scarce a mile behind us
When we made 'em out
Seven ships of the line pursuing
Our scouts, it was a dismal sight. With colours flying we gave 'em chase
As fast as we were able;
But soon we saw them scattering
Each ship to save herself. Then we came up with their rear ships
Where gallant action was to be seen
'twas then we learnt they'd scatter'd
And so we took what prize we could. 

Full carp'd at by the Dutch
We'd let one fifty-gun ship escape us,
And fear'd she'd give the game away. A council held, we soon decided
To chase the fugitives
For fear they'd reach the Dutch
And so we steered due East. We scarce had reached the station
When the clouds gave place to the moon,
Which shining bright on the Dutchman
We could see him lurch and list. At ten they hail'd us, but no answer
For fear of being known;
But we could see them plainly
And they could see us too. We could see each other's fleet
As plain as moonlight would allow,

Lead me to heaven, and I will
Praise Your holy name.

Weather Permitting
by Philip Booth

If the weather permits, we'll take the children
To the sands, and watch the mighty surges
Of the Pacific pounding at his feet,
And fetching down deep loads of boulders
From the headlands. 

If the weather permits. 

If the weather permits, we'll show the children
The grey bulk of Alcatraz, fortress
And prison, where the hardest of criminals
Were contained, although it never stopped them
From attempting to escape. If the weather permits. If the weather permits, we'll take the ferry
Back to the wharf, and eat crab salads
And look at the sea-gulls, while at anchor
The ferry lingers, and the sun sinks slowly
Behind the Golden Gate. If the weather permits. 

Author's Note: As the weather in San Francisco can be cooler even in summer, visitors may need to wear warmer clothes, and take the cable-car to Chinatown, and browse the shops, and eat in an excellent Chinese restaurant, the City Hue.

the people of China stood strong,
their voices raised in protest,
until the government gave in and agreed to talk,
the people cheered and embraced,
as the petals of the flowers continued to fall.

So now you're back, and as rugged as ever,

Our British troops rout the French, it's a fact,

Your strategic brilliance was evident from the start,
You led your forces with wisdom and skill,
And never once doubted, or let fear take hold,
You charged forward, ready to face any foe,

Despite the hardships and setbacks along the way,
You never lost focus, or gave up the fight,
You persevered, and your determination showed through,
It was your dedication that kept us alive,
I'm so proud to have had you as our leader,
And I'll always remember your bravery and fearlessness,
You are a true inspiration, and I'm grateful for your service,
To our country, and to all of us.

This poem is all about images that have different meanings for different people. For those who have a visual identity, it can be hard to express themselves with words, but by seeing something once or twice, people create connections. For those with a conceptual identity, it's much harder to express why an image is interesting or meaningful. 

What images evoke for an individual? 

"What is the image?" may be the first question that comes to mind. For someone else, looking "that" way or seeing "that" image and knowing they are looking at it "that way" may cause thoughts of that image to pop up. For another, being familiar with an image can bring meaning to the image. Some people find meaning from the way an image looks, and others see it as a representation of themselves. 

For the person looking at a piece of art for the first time, it could be all about that image.A person's identity may have roots in their past with images. 

A new artist may be attracted by the same images or ideas that have already captivated others. 

Even when a person is trying to understand how concepts of identity tie into images they have encountered, it may take time to find the answer. A new viewer may see "the image," but it does not necessarily mean the image makes him or her a different person. 

"What is this piece doing to you and how is this looking into your mind?" can be a very common and helpful question to ask when trying to understand images.For many of us, images can be powerful sources of ideas about ourselves. We can use images as guides, as a vehicle for communication, or as a place to seek new things. 

An image is usually taken in one moment; it can be a very powerful source of inspiration for an individual, but it has several limitations. For most of us, images are often limited to specific places, times, or forms of life. The fact that images are more often than not limited to one place or one time can cause a person to feel as though the image has no meaning. 

Images often look and feel very "limited"but they are not. 

We see in our dreams the same kind of images, but in the dream we know we are dreaming because we know what an image is and we are not fooled because we see a world that is quite different from our own.

So go out there and shine your light on the world. 

Shine your light on the people who need you most. Shine your light on those who have no hope. Shine your light on those who don't deserve it. Shine your light on those who will never know happiness. 

But shine your light anyway. 

Because if you do, then maybe they'll see the light too.

A Grammarians Funeral

Shortly after the revival of learning,

A great grammarian died;

They huddled round his bier to burn him,

And all the while he cried:

"Oh, leave me to my books and learning,

And do not touch my dust;

For if you do, you'll only find

A pedant and a crust." The moral of this story is:

Don't be a pedant or you'll end up like this grammarian!

The Argument

Satan, now repenting of his rebellion, and fearing the torments that he is to undergo, resolves to return to heaven, and to submit to God. His design is discovered by Uriel, who, by God's command, drives him from heaven. Satan, after wandering about in the dark for some time, finds Beelzebub, and tells him of his design, which he advises him to abandon. They then consult about what is to be done, and, after some debate, resolve to build a palace in hell, which they accordingly do. 

The poem begins with Satan repenting of his rebellion and fearing the torments that he is to undergo. He resolves to return to heaven and submit to God, but his design is discovered by Uriel. 

Uriel drives him from heaven, and Satan wanders in the dark for some time before finding Beelzebub. 

Satan tells Beelzebub of his design, and Beelzebub advises him to abandon it. 

They debate about what is to be done and resolve to build a palace in hell.

In the heart of the city, where the sun seldom shines,
Stands the House of Fortune, where destiny intertwines. 

Its walls are of marble, its roof of pure gold,
A sight to behold, for the young and the old. The doors are of silver, with a diamond knob,
A place where the hopeful and the desperate often throb. 

The windows are of crystal, clear as a dream,
Reflecting the faces of those who dare to scheme. Inside, the air is thick with the scent of chance,
And the echoes of laughter, sorrow, and romance. The walls are adorned with tales of the past,
Of fortunes won and lost, of shadows cast. In the center, a table, as old as time,
Carved with symbols, each a paradigm. Around it, chairs, for the brave and the bold,
Who dare to play the game, their futures to hold. The dealer, a figure, shrouded in mystery,
His eyes hold a thousand tales of victory and misery. With a deck of cards, he weaves the fate,
Of those who enter the House's ornate gate. 

Some leave with pockets heavy, hearts light,
Their dreams fulfilled in the soft moonlight. 

Others leave with nothing, but a tale of woe,
Their hopes shattered, their spirits low. Yet, each day, as the sun dips below,
The House of Fortune continues to glow. 

A beacon of hope, a symbol of dread,
In the heart of the city, where fortunes are bred. 

So, step inside, if you dare to dream,
In the House of Fortune, where all is not as it seem. 

For in this game of chance, you may find,
A fortune or ruin, or perhaps, peace of mind.

The waters give it life,
And we must give our lives to save these waters,
And save the life. We're not alone. A tree has no eyes, but it can see,
Feel the breeze, hear the wind in those tiny leaves,
Smell the rain, taste the earth. A mountain's not just a rock
Pushing up from deep within the earth,
But a being with feet and head;
A face and ears, like your own. 

It hears you, listens to your dreams,
Your deepest needs. 

If you could live within a mountain, for a night,
Or longer, you would come to understand. We can travel far, but the best journey is inside
Each of us. 

To the end

Her graceful form was such All were eager eyes on its bright array; And while with looks and words she pleased each one By those who loved could feel their heart made one With hers to stay. 

Fair Kunigunde had won All hearts save but his; he sought to gain Whose own free will alone would make him mine  She felt for me no soft return. Love not my lord, said many lips That gossips bore; That love will yet endure Was better ne'er than known before. No longer I would listen, deaf I grew To every voice but hers; nor ever thought Of joy so bright as twas when eve her foot Had touched the floor oertopped by silver bowed, Where never light at once can seem too proud Or glittering rich in splendour rare, While there was ruddiness on all things fair; Then, with the sun did shine my life-star shone Through darkness, till it fell apart from hence, To let in cool night once again, until My soul within herself lay waiting still For love beyond death to find release. 

And ah! if then I gazed into my grave A moment long? 

I felt around What more had passed than griefs cold hand engraved On its dark bosom, where they laid the stone  Who loves in spirit true hath seen his Queen! As one whose faith has died, whom none remain Alike bereft beside; whose life seems done With what was most itself until that day When all had ended

I am a wordsmith and a poet with multiple poet works and multiple writings in other genres from short stories to a novel. 

My words are my creed. 

My words are my freedom. 

My words will stand as my legacy. 

My words are what I live, eat and breathe. 

My words are my power source. 

This is the most important sentence anyone may ever read. 

I have always told my writing students the same thing in multiple ways: If you have written a book and no one has read it, then you have not written a book. I have said that if you write something and it does not get published, then you have not written anything at all. The key to success as a writer is to have someone say, I read your work. 

I enjoyed it. For those who truly appreciate and enjoy the written word at any level, the act of reading and learning from someone elses work, then I suggest you start to take pen to paper, whether as a hobby or with ambition, and start expressing yourself. I have tried writing this piece in many different ways and with my own voice. 

You see, poetry for me is not the same as prose. 

It is not the same as journalism, an essay or even a short story. It is unique because it is completely and utterly personal and individualistic. The words I am choosing to use are entirely my choice as there is not a set way or proper or incorrect way to word a poetic piece of writing. There is only what feels right when we say it out loud. This freedom of expression in all its various forms of poetic rhyme is unique to the human species and only us humans write poetry. 

Poetry is not only about emotions. It is an art form that expresses through a rhythmic structure words in a precise manner to convey a deeper meaning or feeling. It encompasses various forms of literature and the written word. Poetry is not just about lyrics or rap music. Poetry can be spoken word or musicalized on the radio. I love poetry in its many

In the heart of Beijing, on a day in June,
A tragedy unfolded, a moment of truth. On the streets of Tiananmen Square,
A peaceful protest, a call for fair share. 

The people stood up, their voices raised high,
For democracy and freedom, they would not comply. 

The government responded with force and might,
Crushing the protests, ending the fight. The world watched in horror, as the tanks rolled in,
The sound of gunfire, a chilling din. 

Hundreds of people, their lives cut short,
A moment of darkness, a human cost. But the memory lives on, a flame of hope,
For those who fought, for those who spoke. 

The people of China, will never forget,
The day of June 4th, when their voices were met. And though the government tries to suppress,
The truth will always be a source of stress. For the people of China, their fight will continue,
Until they achieve the freedom they desire to obtain.

A testament to the passing of each day. The trees that once stood tall and proud,
Now withered and fallen to the ground,
The sun blanched blood of the earth is loud,
A mournful cry for all that was once found. 

The rivers that once flowed free and wild,
Now dried up and lifeless, a shadow of their former self,
The sun blanched blood of the earth is mild,
A reminder of the fleeting nature of life on this planet shelf. So let us remember the sun blanched blood of the earth,
And cherish each moment, for life is but a breath,
Let us strive to live with purpose and mirth,
And leave behind a legacy that will never wither or die.
